translated: And this is stated by accepting [the opponent's position].

original: adhunā satkāryavāde janmārtha eva na yukta ityāha /
analyzed: adhunā satkārya vāde janma arthaḥ eva na yuktaḥ iti āha
translated: Now, in the doctrine of existent effects, the meaning of birth itself is not reasonable. He says:

analyzed: sa thas ca ityādi
translated: If it exists... and so on.

analyzed: na eva tasya ca asatvena abhimatasya janma asti
translated: That which is accepted as non-existent does not have birth.

analyzed: sa tvāt
translated: Because it exists.

analyzed: niṣpanna avasthāyām iva iti viruddha vyāpta upalabdhiḥ asya janma asti
translated: As in the accomplished state, there is the apprehension of the contradictory pervasion of its birth.

analyzed: sa tvāt
translated: Because of existence.

analyzed: niṣpanna avasthāyām iva iti viruddha vyāpta upalabdhiḥ asya manasi varttate
translated: As in the accomplished state, there is the apprehension of the contradictory pervasion of its mind.

original: anyathā punarjātasyāpi punarjātiḥ prasajyata ityanavasthā syāt / yadāha /
analyzed: anyathā punar jātasya api punar jātiḥ prasajyate iti anavasthā syāt yat āha
translated: Otherwise, even of what is born again, there would be the fault of the regress of birth, so there would be an infinite regress. As it is said:

original: sato yadi bhavejjanma jātasyāpi bhaved bhava iti /
analyzed: sataḥ yadi bhavet janma jātasya api bhavet bhavaḥ iti
translated: If there were birth of what exists, there would be becoming even of what is born.

original: kiñca sādhanānāṃ kāraṇānāmbījatejojalādīnāṃ vaiphalyaṃ prasajyeta sādhyasya karttavyasya kasyacidrūpasyābhāvāditi /
analyzed: kiñca sādhanānām kāraṇānām bīja tejaḥ jala ādīnām vaiphalyam prasajyeta sādhyasya karttavyasya kasyacid rūpasya abhāvāt iti
translated: Moreover, there would be the fault of the futility of the means, the causes, such as seed, fire, water, etc., because of the absence of any form of the effect to be accomplished.

analyzed: prayogaḥ
translated: The argument is:

original: yatra sādhyanna kiñcidapyasti tatra sādhanasāphalyaṃ vidyate yathā nabhasyanādheyātiśaye /
analyzed: yatra sādhyat na kiñcid api asti tatra sādhana sāphalyam vidyate yathā nabhasi anādheya atiśaye
translated: Where there is nothing at all to be accomplished, there is the success of the means, as in the case of the sky, which does not have any property to be added.

original: na ca sādhyaṅkiñcidapyasti kāraṇe vyavasthite sati kāryaṃ iti vyāpakānupalabdhiḥ /
analyzed: na ca sādhyam kiñcid api asti kāraṇe vyavasthite sati kāryam iti vyāpaka anupalabdhiḥ
translated: And there is nothing at all to be accomplished, because when the effect is established in the cause, there is the non-apprehension of the pervasion.

analyzed: na ca ayam asiddhaḥ hetuḥ iti mantavyam
translated: And this reason should not be thought to be unestablished.

original: yasmād yasya kasyacidatiśayasya tatra kāraṇe sthite kārye kathañcidutpattāviṣyamāṇāyāṃ sotiśayastatrāsan kathañjāyeta naiva jāyetāsatvāt /
analyzed: yasmāt yasya kasyacid atiśayasya tatra kāraṇe sthite kārye kathañcid utpattau iṣyamāṇāyām saḥ utiśayaḥ tatra asan katham jāyeta na eva jāyeta a sattvāt
translated: Because when the effect is about to arise in some way when the cause of some particular thing is present, how could that particular thing arise there without existing? It would not arise at all due to non-existence.

original: vyomotpalamiva dugdha iti vyāpakānupalabdhirasya cetasi sthitā /
analyzed: vyoma utpalam iva dugdhe iti vyāpaka anupalabdhiḥ asya cetasi sthitā
translated: Like milk from a sky-lotus. The non-apprehension of the pervasion of this is present in the mind.

analyzed: atha āsan api atiśayaḥ jāyate
translated: Now, if a particular thing arises even though it does not exist,

original: tadā jātau vā tasyāsatopi sarvvotiśayaḥ sarvasmājjāyeteti tulyaḥ paryanuyoga iti /
analyzed: tadā jātau vā tasya asataḥ api sarva utiśayaḥ sarvasmāt jāyeta iti tulyaḥ paryanuyogaḥ iti
translated: then when it arises, that non-existent particular thing would arise from everything. The same objection applies.

analyzed: bhavataḥ api dhṛta atiśayaḥ api tilebhyaḥ utpadyeta asattvāt  tena atiśayavat iti arthaḥ
translated: Even for you, a particular thing held to exist would arise from sesame seeds due to non-existence.

analyzed: svabhāva hetu prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is like a particular thing. It is a logical fallacy of intrinsic nature.

analyzed: para matam āśaṅkate
translated: He suspects the opponent's opinion.

analyzed: na atiśayaḥ tatra ityādinā
translated: Beginning with There is no particular thing there, etc.

original: yathā nāsti sa kathantatrāsan prakāro jāyeteti prakṣipati /
analyzed: yathā na asti sa katham tatra asan prakāraḥ jāyeta iti prakṣipati
translated: He asks how, if it does not exist, that non-existent form could arise there.

original: jāto vā sarvvaḥ sarvvasmājjāyeteti tulyaḥ paryanuyoga iti pūrvokto doṣo'nu yujyata ityabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: jātaḥ vā sarvaḥ sarvasmāt jāyeta iti tulyaḥ paryanuyogaḥ iti pūrva uktaḥ doṣaḥ nu yujyate iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: Or, if it arises, the same objection applies that everything would arise from everything. The fault stated earlier is applicable, this is the intention.

analyzed: sarva prakāreṇa eva tarhi niṣpanna rūpa atiśayaḥ usti iti ced āha
translated: If it is argued that then the form of the accomplished particular thing exists in every way, he says:

analyzed: na ca ityādi
translated: And it is not, etc.

analyzed: evam tāvat sat asat kārya vādinoḥ sarvvasmāt sarvasya utpatti doṣaḥ tulyaḥ iti pratipāditam
translated: Thus, it has been shown that the fault of everything arising from everything applies equally to the proponents of existent and nonexistent effects.

original: na ca tayorapi tulyañcodyanna tadeko vaktumarhati /
analyzed: na ca tayoḥ api tulyam codyat na tat ekaḥ vaktum arhati
translated: And the objection is the same for both, so one should not speak of it.

original: satkāryavāde ca na kaścijjanmārtha iti prasādhitaṃ tenāyamastītyadhiko doṣaḥ /
analyzed: satkārya vāde ca na kaścid janma arthaḥ iti prasādhitam tena ayam asti iti adhikaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: And in the doctrine of existent effects, there is no purpose for arising, as has been established. Therefore, this is an additional fault.

original: tadevaṅkadācitparo'bhidadhyānnanu bho yadi nāma mayaitanna parihṛtaṃ bhavatā tvavasyaṃ /
analyzed: tat evam kadācid paras abhidadhyāt nanu bho yadi nāma mayā etat na parihṛtam bhavatā tu avasyam
translated: Thus, if the opponent were to say at some point, Well, if this has not been refuted by me, it must be refuted by you,

original: śyaṃ sthiteḥ kiñcit svapakṣasya rakṣaṇāya vācyaṃ /
analyzed: sthiteḥ kiñcid sva pakṣasya rakṣaṇāya vācyam
translated: since the opponent's position is established, something must be said to protect one's own position.

original: nahi parasya pakṣaṃ dūṣayatā svapakṣasthitiranavadyā labhyate /
analyzed: nahi parasya pakṣam dūṣayatā sva pakṣa sthitiḥ anavadyā labhyate
translated: For one who refutes the opponent's position does not attain an irreproachable establishment of one's own position.

analyzed: na bhavati nityaḥ śabdaḥ mūrtta tvāt
translated: Sound is not eternal, because it is corporeal.

analyzed: sukha ādibhiḥ vyabhicāreṇa ityādau anitya tvā siddha vat iti atas āha
translated: In the case of over-pervasion by pleasure etc., it is like the unestablished reason. To this, he says:

original: asatopi kāryasya kāraṇādutpāde yo yajjananasvabhāvastata eva tasya janma nānyasmāditi niyama iti /
analyzed: asataḥ api kāryasya kāraṇāt utpāde yaḥ yad janana svabhāvaḥ tatas eva tasya janma na anyasmāt iti niyamaḥ iti
translated: Even for the arising of an existent effect from a cause, the rule is that it arises only from that which has the nature of producing it, not from anything else.

analyzed: api śabdaḥ sambhāvanāyām
translated: The word api (even) is used in the sense of possibility.🔽This is the truth of the matter here: Even though the nonexistent oil arises from sesame seeds,

analyzed: idam atra artha tatvam avidyamānam api tailam tilebhyaḥ eva utpadyate
translated: it arises only from sesame seeds.

analyzed: tad utpādana śakti yukta tvāt tilānām na anyasmāt tad jana śakti vikala tvāt tasya
translated: Because sesamum seeds possess the power to produce that [oil], not from anything else, because that [oil] is devoid of the power to generate it.

original: śaktipratiniyama eva ca kathamiti ca paryanuyoge vastusvabhāvairuttaraṃ vācyaṃ /
analyzed: śakti pratiniyamaḥ eva ca katham iti ca paryanuyoge vastu svabhāvaiḥ uttaram vācyam
translated: And when questioned as to how there can be restriction of power, the answer must be given in terms of the nature of things.

original: ya evambhavanti yathā vā tathaiva pradhānānmahān eva jāyate nāhaṅkāro mahato'haṅkāro na pañcatanmātrāṇītyādi prakriyā /
analyzed: ye evam bhavanti yathā vā tathā eva pradhānāt mahān eva jāyate na ahaṅkāraḥ mahataḥ uhaṅkāraḥ na pañca tanmātrāṇi ityādi prakriyā
translated: The great one is born from primordial matter in the same way and by the same process as it exists, not ego-mastery, and from the great one ego-mastery, not the five subtle elements, and so on.

analyzed: tatra ca bhavataḥ śakti pratiniyama avalambanam eva śaraṇam
translated: And in that case, for you, the only refuge is to rely on the restriction of power.

analyzed: anyasya parihāra upāyasya abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no other means of reply.

analyzed: tadet ca na mama api kākena bhakṣitam
translated: And that is not eaten by a crow for me either.

original: tena yaduktannahyasatve kaścid viśeṣa iti tadayuktimat /
analyzed: tena yat uktam na hi asatve kaścid viśeṣaḥ iti tat ayuktimat
translated: Therefore, what was said - that there is no difference in the absence of existence - is illogical.

analyzed: kāraṇa sāmarthya asāmarthya kṛta tvāt kārya utpati anutpatyoḥ
translated: Because the production or non-production of an effect is due to the capability or incapability of the cause.

analyzed: tasmāt puronukrāntayoḥ pramāṇayoḥ sandigdha vipakṣa vyāvṛttika tva sādhana kalaṅka aṅkitaḥ hetuḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the reason is tainted with the blemish of proving what is already established in the two means of knowledge previously presented, as it has doubtful exclusion from the counter-example.

analyzed: bhavet etat tasya api hetoḥ tad janana svabhāva niyamaḥ
translated: This could be so, if that reason also had the restriction of being of the nature to generate that [effect].

analyzed: kutas jātaḥ iti atas āha
translated: From where did it arise? To this he says:

analyzed: tasya api sa svabhāva niyamaḥ
translated: That also has a restriction of its own nature.

analyzed: sva hetoḥ iti
translated: From its own cause.

analyzed: tasya api sa kutas iti ced āha
translated: If it is asked how that also has it, he says:

analyzed: iti evam anādi bhāva svabhāva niyamaḥ iti
translated: Thus, the restriction of the nature of existence is beginningless.

original: na vidyate ādirasyeti vigrahaḥ /🔽anāditvābhyupagamāddhetuphalaprakṛti paraṃparāyā nānavasthādoṣo laghīyasīmapi kṣatimāvahatyanyathā'dau kalpyamāne tasyāhetukatvaprasaṅgastenāsthāna
analyzed: na vidyate ādiḥ asya iti vigrahaḥ  anādi tva abhyupagamāt hetu phala prakṛti paraṃparāyāḥ nā anavasthā doṣaḥ laghīyasīm api kṣatim āvahati anyathā ādau kalpyamāne tasya ahetuka tva prasaṅgaḥ tena asthāna
translated: The analysis is: it does not have a beginning.

analyzed: eva iyam āśaṅkā bhavataḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Because the beginninglessness is accepted, there is no fault of infinite regress in the series of causes and effects. Otherwise, if it were imagined at the beginning, it would follow that it is without a cause. Therefore, this doubt is only for you. This is the meaning.

analyzed: athavā anyathā ayam granthaḥ vyākhyāyate
translated: Or else, this text is explained in another way.

analyzed: niṣparyāyeṇa āsannā eva tarhi atiśayaḥ jāyate
translated: If it is not in succession, then indeed the excess is produced.

analyzed: na ca sarvvam sarvvasmāt jāyeta iti paryanuyojyam
translated: And it should not be argued that everything is produced from everything.

original: yo yajjananasvabhāvastata eva tasyātiśayotpattiriti śaktiniyamasamāśrayāditi kadācitsvasiddhāntamanādṛtyāpi parobhidadhātyāśaṅkāyāṃ na mamāpyetacchaktipratiniyamāvalamvanaṅkenaciddaṇḍena
analyzed: yaḥ yad janana svabhāvaḥ tatas eva tasya atiśaya utpattiḥ iti śakti niyama samāśrayāt iti kadācid sva siddhāntam an ādṛtya api paraḥ abhidadhāti āśaṅkāyām na mama api etad śakti pratiniyama avalamvanaṅkenacid daṇḍena
translated: That which has the nature of producing something, from that alone there is the production of its excess. Because it depends on the restriction of power, sometimes even disregarding one's own established doctrine, one may imagine in doubt. Even for me, this restriction of power is not prevented by any punishment.

analyzed: nivāritam iti āgūrya āha
translated: Out of respect, he says:

analyzed: asataḥ api ityādi
translated: Even of the non-existent, etc.

analyzed: pada vibhāgaḥ tu pūrvavat
translated: But the division of words is as before.

original: prayogo /prayogaḥ punaryasya yajjananāya samarthaṃ kāraṇamasti sosannapi jāyata eva yathātiśayaviśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: prayogo prayogaḥ punar yasya yat jananāya samartham kāraṇam asti saḥ usan api jāyate eva yathā atiśaya viśeṣaḥ
translated: The argument is as follows: Whatever has a cause capable of producing it, even if it is close, is produced, like a particular excess.

analyzed: tad jananāya samartham kāraṇam asti ca kārya viśeṣasya iti svabhāva hetuḥ
translated: And there is a cause capable of producing that particular effect, so this is an inference from essential nature.

original: tathā yo yatrāvidyamānatajjananasamarthakāraṇaḥ sa tatrāsatvepi nodeti /
analyzed: tathā yaḥ yatra avidyamāna tad janana samartha kāraṇaḥ sa tatra asattve pi nā udeti
translated: Similarly, whatever does not have a cause capable of producing it in something, does not arise there even if it is not present.

original: yathā tileṣu dhṛtātiśayastathā cāvidyamānatajananasamarthakāranaḥ kāryaviśeṣaḥ kāraṇaviśeṣa iti vyāpakānupalabdhiḥ /
analyzed: yathā tileṣu dhṛta atiśayaḥ tathā ca avidyamāna tajanana samartha kāranaḥ kārya viśeṣaḥ kāraṇa viśeṣaḥ iti vyāpaka anupalabdhiḥ
translated: Like the excess of oil in sesame seeds. And the particular effect does not have a cause capable of producing it, so this is the non-apprehension of the pervasion.

analyzed: apara paryyāyaḥ
translated: Another way of stating it is:

analyzed: sādhanasya liṅgasya
translated: The reason, the means of proof,

analyzed: sat akāraṇāt upādāna grahaṇāt sarvva sambhava abhāvāt
translated: is not a cause of what exists, because of the inclusion of the material cause, and because of the absence of the possibility of everything.

analyzed: śakyasya śakya karaṇāt kāraṇa bhāvāt ca satkāryam
translated: And because of the production of what is possible, and because of the existence of the cause, the effect exists.

analyzed: iti evamādeḥ vaiphalyam
translated: Such statements are useless.

analyzed: sādhyasya kartavyasya kasyacid saṃśaya viparyāsa vyavacchedasya niścaya pratyaya janmanaḥ ca abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no need to remove doubt or error regarding anything to be accomplished, and because there is no arising of certainty from conditions.

original: sarvvaṃ hi sādhanaṃ vivādapade vastuni saṃśayaviparyāsāvapanayantadviṣayanniścayapratyayamutpādayadvibhartti nāmānurūpaṃ na dvayamapyetat kāpilamate
analyzed: sarvvam hi sādhanam vivāda pade vastuni saṃśaya viparyāsau apanayan tat viṣayat niścaya pratyayam utpādayat vibhartti nāma anurūpam na dvayam api etat kāpila mate
translated: For every means of knowledge is so called because it removes doubt and error regarding the object of dispute and produces the cognition of certainty regarding that object. This twofold definition is appropriate. But in the Sāṃkhya doctrine,

analyzed: sambhavati
translated: it is not possible.

analyzed: sadā avasthitasya kāryasya hāni upajanana ayogāt
translated: Because the effect, which is always present, cannot be destroyed or produced.

original: atha sannapyayaṃ niścayaḥ sādhanavacanādanabhivyaktaṃ pūrvvamabhivyaktimupayātyato na vaiphalyamiti matamata āha /
analyzed: atha san api ayam niścayaḥ sādhana vacanāt anabhivyaktam pūrvvam abhivyaktim upayāti atas na vaiphalyam iti matam atas āha
translated: Now, if it is the view that this certainty, though existent, was previously unexpressed and now attains expression due to the statement of the means of knowledge, so it is not useless, he says:

original: yasya kasyacidatiśayasyābhivyaktilakṣaṇasya tatra sādhye niścayarūpe kathañcidasat utpattau prātpātsādhanāt so'tiśayastatrāsan kathañjāyate🔽jāto vā sarvvātiśayaḥ /
analyzed: yasya kasyacid atiśayasya abhivyakti lakṣaṇasya tatra sādhye niścaya rūpe kathañcid asat utpattau saḥ utiśayaḥ tatra asan kathan jāyate  jātaḥ vā sarvva atiśayaḥ
translated: How can that excess, which is of the nature of expression in that to be proved, which is of the nature of certainty, be produced from the means of knowledge, when it is somehow non-existent? That excess, which was non-existent there, how is it produced?

original: samastasādhyaniścayābhivyaktilakṣaṇaḥ sarvvasmādanyasādhanāt sādhanābhāsāt votpadyeteti tulyaḥ prasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: samasta sādhya niścaya abhivyakti lakṣaṇaḥ sarvvasmāt anya sādhanāt sādhana ābhāsāt vā utpadyeta iti tulyaḥ prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Or if produced, it is produced from all other means of knowledge, or from the means of knowledge that is not a means of knowledge.

analyzed: pāvaka ādi pratipatti hetavaḥ dhūma ādayaḥ satkārya viniścaya ādi abhivyaktim kuryuḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that smoke and other causes of the cognition of fire would produce the expression of the ascertainment of the existent effect.

analyzed: utpattya ca abhivyaktim etat ucyate
translated: And this is said to be manifestation by origination.

original: natviyamavikṛtarūpeṣu kṛtāspadā sā hi tatsvarūpalakṣaṇā tadviṣayajñānalakṣaṇā /
analyzed: na tu iyam avikṛta rūpeṣu kṛta āspadā sā hi tad svarūpa lakṣaṇā tad viṣaya jñāna lakṣaṇā
translated: But this is not established in those whose form is unchanged. For that is characterized by its own nature, characterized by the knowledge of that object.

original: rūpāntaraprādurbhāvalakṣaṇābhāvā bhavetsvarūpaṃ tāvat avikāryamiti na sādhanairanyairvā kartuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: rūpa antara prādurbhāva lakṣaṇa abhāvāḥ bhavet svarūpam tāvat avikāryam iti na sādhanaiḥ anyaiḥ vā kartum śakyate
translated: It would be in the absence of the characteristic of the appearance of another form. The own nature, indeed, is unchangeable, so it cannot be made by means of proofs or anything else.

original: vikāre vā pūrvvasvabhāvavāniva pūrvvarūpaprādurbhāvaścetyasatkāryavāda eva samarthitaḥ pūrvāpararūpatyāgāvāptilakṣānatvāt vikārasya /
analyzed: vikāre vā pūrvva svabhāvavān iva pūrva rūpa prādurbhāvaḥ ca iti asatkārya vādaḥ eva samarthitaḥ pūrva apara rūpa tyāga avāpti lakṣa anatvāt vikārasya
translated: Or in modification, the appearance of the previous form would be as if having the previous nature, thus the doctrine of non-existent effect is supported, because modification is characterized by the abandonment and acquisition of the previous and subsequent forms.

original: caitanyasyaikatvādaparastadviṣayaḥ pratyayo na bhavati parasyeti tadrūpābhivyaktiranupapannā /
analyzed: caitanyasya eka tvāt aparaḥ tad viṣayaḥ pratyayaḥ na bhavati parasya iti tad rūpa abhivyaktiḥ anupapannā
translated: And because consciousness is one, there is no other cognition of that object belonging to another, so the manifestation of that form is not possible.

original: rūpāntaraprādurbhāve ca nānyasya kiṃcidapyupajāyate vilakṣaṇatvāditi tṛtīyāpi vyaktirasambhavinī dvitīyāyāmapyayamanivārito doṣaḥ /
analyzed: rūpa antara prādurbhāve ca na anyasya kiṃcid api upajāyate vilakṣaṇa tvāt iti tṛtīyā api vyaktiḥ asambhavinī dvitīyāyām api ayam anivāritaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: And in the appearance of another form, nothing at all arises for another, because of being different, so the third manifestation is also impossible. In the second also, this fault is unavoidable.

analyzed: tad viṣaya pratyaya udaye pi artha antarasya abhūta bhāva vaiparītyasya vyakteḥ ayogāt
translated: Even in the arising of the cognition of that object, the manifestation of the opposite of non-existent existence of another object is not proper.

analyzed: na ca an upakārakaḥ pratyayasya viṣayaḥ sambhavī
translated: And a non-benefactor cannot be the object of cognition.

analyzed: tad upakāraka tve vā tasmāt eva asya utpattiḥ iti liṅga anapekṣā
translated: Or, if it is helpful to that, then its origination is from that alone, so the inferential mark is not necessary.

analyzed: svatas eva sādhya niścayaḥ usya abhivyaktiḥ iti prāptam
translated: It is obtained that its manifestation is the ascertainment of the probandum from itself.

original: sādhanāpekṣādeva sādhyaniścayāt svaviṣayajñānotpādenaivāpekṣātiśayotpattilakṣaṇāsthireṣu labdhāspadeti pratipāditaṃ sarvvadā vā bhavet /
analyzed: sādhana apekṣāt eva sādhya niścayāt sva viṣaya jñāna utpādena eva apekṣā atiśaya utpatti lakṣaṇa asthireṣu labdha āspadā iti pratipāditam sarvvadā vā bhavet
translated: Because the ascertainment of the probandum is dependent on the means of knowledge itself, and because the means of knowledge is established by the mere production of knowledge of its own object, it is established that it is not stable.

analyzed: liṅgasya api sadā sannihita rūpa tvāt
translated: Because the inferential mark also always has the form of being present.

analyzed: liṅga jñāna apekṣāyām api tulyaḥ
translated: Even if it is dependent on the knowledge of the inferential mark, it is the same.

analyzed: tasya api sattve vādinaḥ sarvva kāla astitvāt iti
translated: Because the proponent always exists when that [knowledge of the inferential mark] exists.

analyzed: api ca ityādinā satkārya vāda nirākaraṇe kāraṇa antaram āha
translated: And beginning with Moreover, he states another reason for the refutation of the doctrine of the effect being existent.

analyzed: tad avasthāyām iti
translated: In that state means.

analyzed: mṛd piṇḍa avasthāyām paścāt vat abhivyakta avasthāyām iva tad arthakriyā iti ghaṭa sādhya udaka dhāraṇa viśeṣa arthakriyā
translated: Like the manifest state after the state of the lump of clay, the operation for that purpose is the operation of holding water, which is to be accomplished by the pot.

analyzed: vyakteḥ aviśiṣṭa saṃsthānāyāḥ aprādurbhāvāt iti ced
translated: If it is said that it is because the manifestation does not appear with a distinct configuration,

analyzed: parama tā āsaṅkā
translated: it is a suspicion of the opponent's view.

analyzed: śaṅkā tasyāḥ eva ityādi pratividhānam
translated: The response beginning with That very [manifestation] is the refutation.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: grīvādisanniveśaviśeṣāvacchinna eṣorthakriyāviśeṣakārī kaścit mṛdvikāro ghaṭa ityacyute nānyaḥ /
analyzed: grīvā ādi sanniveśa viśeṣa avacchinnaḥ eṣa ṛthakriyā viśeṣa kārī kaścid mṛd vikāraḥ ghaṭaḥ iti acyute na anyaḥ
translated: This modification of clay, which is qualified by the particular arrangement of the neck and other parts, is the pot, which performs a particular function, and nothing else.

original: sa cet prāgapi mṛtpiṇḍāvasthāyāmapi tadāvyaktāvasthāyāmiva tadarthakriyopalbdhau syātāṃ /
analyzed: sa ced prāk api mṛd piṇḍa avasthāyām api tadā avyakta avasthāyām iva tad artha kriyā upalbdhau syātām
translated: If it existed even before, in the state of the lump of clay, just as it is not manifest in that state, it would be perceived in the performance of its function.

original: na ca bhavatastasmānnāstyevāsāviti niścayaḥ sāmādhī yatāṃ kimalīkanirbandheneti /
analyzed: na ca bhavataḥ tasmāt na asti eva asau iti niścayaḥ sāmādhī yatām kim alīka nirbandhena iti
translated: And since you do not have the certainty that it does not exist at all, what is the point of this futile insistence?

analyzed: avasthātuḥ bhāvāt asau api asti iti ced āha
translated: If it is argued that it exists because of the existence of the state, it is said:

analyzed: nahi rūpa antarasya bhāve rūpa antaram asti
translated: For when there is the existence of one form, another form does not exist.

analyzed: pītaḥ iva nīlam iti viruddha vyāpta upalabdhiḥ ākūtā
translated: Just as blue does not exist when yellow is seen. This is the apprehension of the pervasion of a contradiction.

analyzed: na ca avasthā avasthātroḥ abhedāt asiddhaḥ hetuḥ iti garjitavyam
translated: And it should not be thundered that the reason is not established because the state and the possessor of the state are non-different.

analyzed: yasmāt na ca rūpa pratibhāsa bhede pi vastu bhedaḥ yuktaḥ
translated: Because it is not proper to distinguish the difference in form even when there is a difference in the appearance of form.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt
translated: Because of the great absurdity.

analyzed: rūpa pratibhāsa bheda grahaṇam upalakṣaṇa artham
translated: The mention of the difference in the appearance of form is for the purpose of illustration.

analyzed: tena artha kriyā bhedaḥ api abhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, the difference in function must also be accepted.

analyzed: evam manyate
translated: This is what is thought.

original: yadi bhinnapratibhāsi jñānaṃ bhedaṃ sādhayati tadā sukhaduḥkhamohānāṃ asaṅkīrṇā bhedavyavasthā bhavet /
analyzed: yadi bhinna pratibhāsi jñānam bhedam sādhayati tadā sukha duḥkha mohānām asaṅkīrṇā bheda vyavasthā bhavet
translated: If cognition appearing as different establishes difference, then the distinct arrangement of pleasure, pain, and delusion would be unmixed.

original: nānyathā tathā ca mṛtpiṇḍaghaṭayorapi parasparamatyaṃtambheda iti pratijānīmahe /
analyzed: na anyathā tathā ca mṛd piṇḍa ghaṭayoḥ api parasparam atyaṃtam bhedaḥ iti pratijānīmahe
translated: Otherwise, we assert that even between a lump of clay and a pot, there is absolute difference from each other.

analyzed: bhinna ākāra jñāna paricchedya tvāt
translated: Because they are to be delimited by cognitions of different forms.

analyzed: paraspara asambhavi kārya kāri tvāt ca sukha ādi vat iti svabhāva hetū
translated: And because they are mutually non-concomitant causes and effects, like pleasure etc. This is a reason based on nature.

analyzed: anyathā sukha ādīnām api parasparam abheda prasaṅgaḥ śakti vyakti vat
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of even pleasure etc. being non-different from each other, like potency and manifestation.

analyzed: viśeṣaḥ vā vācyaḥ iti
translated: Or a distinction must be stated.

original: tasmādityupasaṃhāraḥ /🔽nahi tasya ghaṭadestasminnupalabdhilakṣaṇaprāpte svabhāve sthitau satyāmanupalabdhiryujyate /
analyzed: tasmāt iti upasaṃhāraḥ  nahi tasya ghaṭa deḥ tasmin upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāpte svabhāve sthitau satyām anupalabdhiḥ yujyate
translated: Therefore is the conclusion.🔽For when that nature of the pot, which is attained by the characteristic of perception, is present, its non-perception is not tenable.

original: athāpi bhavati tadā'sthitiśca tasminsvabhāve'tatvamatatsvabhāatvamupalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptātsvabhāvādekāntena bheda iti yāvat /
analyzed: atha api bhavati tad āsthitiḥ ca tasmin svabhāvetatvam atatsvabhāatvam upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptāt svabhāvāt ekāntena bhedaḥ iti yāvat
translated: But if it does occur, then its non-existence in that nature is that non-existence of that nature. It is absolute difference from the nature attained by the characteristic of perception. This is the extent of it.

analyzed: evam sva bhāā anupalabdhau sādhana aṅga samarthanam prapañcena abhidhāya pariśiṣṭāsu anupalabdhiṣu ācikhyāsuḥ āha
translated: Having thus explained in detail the establishment of the component of proof in the non-apprehension of own nature, he says to explain the remaining non-apprehensions:

analyzed: vyāpaka anupalabdhau ityādi
translated: In the non-apprehension of the pervader, etc.

original: dharmayoryathā śiṃśapātvavṛkḍatvayorvyāpyavyāpakabhāvaṃ kenacitpramāṇena prasādhya vyāpakasya vṛkṣatvādernnivṛttiprasādhanaṃ samarthanaṃ sādhanāṅgasyetyadhyāhāraḥ
analyzed: dharmayoḥ yathā śiṃśapā tva vṛkḍa tvayoḥ vyāpya vyāpaka bhāvam kenacid pramāṇena prasādhya vyāpakasya vṛkṣa tva ādeḥ nivṛtti prasādhanam samarthanam sādhana aṅgasya iti adhyāhāraḥ
translated: The relation of pervaded and pervader between two properties, like being a shimshapa tree and being a tree, is established by some means of knowledge. The establishment of the absence of the pervader, like being a tree, is the establishment of the component of proof. This is to be supplied.

analyzed: yathā na asti atra śiṃśapā vṛkṣa abhāvāt iti
translated: For example, There is no shimshapa tree here because of the absence of a tree.

original: nanu tatra svabhāvānupalabdhyaiva tadabhāvaḥ sidhyati tatkimanayā /
analyzed: nanu tatra svabhāva anupalabdhyā eva tad abhāvaḥ sidhyati tat kim anayā
translated: But there, the absence of that is established by the non-apprehension of own nature itself. Then what is the use of this?

original: nahi niṣpāditakriye karmaṇāṃ viśeṣādhāyi sādhu sādhanambhavati /
analyzed: nahi niṣpādita kriye karmaṇām viśeṣa ādhāyi sādhu sādhanam bhavati
translated: For it is not good to employ means of proof to add something to what has already been accomplished.

analyzed: sādhakatamaṅkaraṇam iti pāṇiniḥ
translated: Panini says that the most effective instrument is the means of proof.

analyzed: vacanāt anadhigata artha ādi gama rūpam ca pramāṇam uktam ajñāta artha prakāśaḥ vā iti
translated: And a means of knowledge is said to be that which reveals an unknown object, as stated in the statement The means of knowledge is that which reveals the unknown.

analyzed: satyam etat
translated: This is true.

analyzed: tathā hi na iyam sarvvatra prayujyate
translated: For this is not employed everywhere.

analyzed: kin tarhi vyoma gata trapā ādi mātre yatra sāla sarala palāśa śiṃśapā ādi pādapa bheda avadhāraṇat na asti tatra
translated: But rather, in mere space, where there is no determination of the difference of trees like sāl, sarala, palāśa, śiṃśapā, etc.

original: sarvvathā yatraiva vyāpyā bhāvo na niścīyate kvacit kutaścid bhrāntinimittāt tatraveyaṃ prayujyate /
analyzed: sarvvathā yatra eva vyāpyāḥ bhāvaḥ na niścīyate kvacid kutaścid bhrānti nimittāt tatravā iyam prayujyate
translated: In all cases, where the presence of the pervaded is not ascertained anywhere due to some cause of error, there this [reason] is used.

original: kāraṇānupalabdhirapi yatra kāryābhāvo naniścīyate tatraiva prayoktavyā nānyatra vaiyarthyāt /
analyzed: kāraṇa anupalabdhiḥ api yatra kārya abhāvaḥ na niścīyate tatra eva prayoktavyā na anyatra vaiyarthyāt
translated: The non-apprehension of the cause should also be employed only where the absence of the effect is not ascertained, not elsewhere, because it would be pointless.

analyzed: yathā santamase dhūma abhāva aniścaye na asti atra dhūma ugni abhāvāt iti
translated: For example, in darkness, when the absence of smoke is not ascertained, [one says:] There is no smoke here because there is no fire.

analyzed: kārya abhāve saṃśayāt
translated: Because there is doubt about the absence of the effect.

original: kāraṇābhāve ca niścayāt /🔽svabhāvaviruddhopalabdhirapi saṃgaviṣayabhāvāvasthitagātrasparśavālākalāpākulānalālīḍha eva vyomādimātravartinirdeśe prayoktavyā /
analyzed: kāraṇa abhāve ca niścayāt  svabhāva viruddha upalabdhiḥ api saṃga viṣaya bhāva avasthita gātra sparśa vālā kalāpa ākula anala ālīḍhe eva vyoma ādi mātra varti nirdeśe prayoktavyā
translated: And because there is certainty about the absence of the cause.🔽The apprehension of what is incompatible by nature should also be used only in mere space, where the touch of the body of a woman who is in a state of existence with a lover is not seen, and where there is no disturbance from the flames of a fire.

analyzed: kāraṇa viruddha upalabdhiḥ ca api adṛśyamāna kamā roma udgama danta vīṇā ādi bheda bhāva ābhā vākya śakya ga anu samīpa avasthita puruṣa samākrānta bhū tale eva prakṛtena anyatra
translated: And the apprehension of what is incompatible with the cause should also be used only in a place occupied by a man who is nearby and whose bodily hair, teeth, and musical instrument, etc. are not visible, not elsewhere,

analyzed: vaiphalyāt
translated: because it would be pointless.

analyzed: anayā ādisā diśā anyāsām api anupalabdhīnām prayoga viṣayaḥ nusarttavyaḥ iti
translated: In this way, the scope of application of the other non-apprehensions should be followed.

analyzed: teṣām svabhāva vyāpaka kāraṇānām
translated: Of those intrinsic natures, pervaders, and causes.

analyzed: viruddhāḥ teṣām upalabdhayaḥ tāsu iti vigrahaḥ
translated: Their apprehensions are contradictory in those. This is the analysis.

analyzed: dvayoḥ virodhayoḥ madhye ekasya upadarśanam
translated: The demonstration of one of the two contradictions.

analyzed: dvau punar virodhau avikala kāraṇasya bhavataḥ nyabhāve bhāvaḥ
translated: Moreover, the two contradictions are: the existence of one with the other in the case of an incomplete cause,

analyzed: paraspara parihāra sthita lakṣaṇaḥ ca
translated: and the characteristic of mutual exclusion.

original: anayā diśā svabhāvaviruddhakāryopalabdhyādiṣvapi sādhanāṅgasamarthanaṃ sujñānameveti noktaṃ /🔽tathāpi kiñcinmātraprayogabhedādekādaśānupalabdhivyatiriktāsvapi kāraṇaviruddhavyāptopalabdhikāryaviruddhavyāptopalabdhivyāpakaviruddhakāryopalabdhikāryaviruddhakāryopalabdhyādiṣu
analyzed: anayā diśā svabhāva viruddha kārya upalabdhi ādiṣu api sādhana aṅga samarthanam su jñānam evā iti na uktam  tathā api kiñcid mātra prayoga bhedāt ekādaśa anupalabdhi vyatiriktāsu api kāraṇa viruddha vyāpta upalabdhi kārya viruddha vyāpta upalabdhi vyāpaka viruddha kārya upalabdhi kārya viruddha kārya upalabdhi ādiṣu
translated: By this direction, the establishment of the components of the proof in the case of the apprehension of an effect contradictory to the intrinsic nature, etc. is very easy to understand, so it is not stated.

analyzed: sādhana aṅga samarthanam uktam veditavyam
translated: Nevertheless, the establishment of the components of the proof should be understood to be stated in the case of the apprehension of a contradictory pervaded cause, the apprehension of a contradictory pervaded effect, the apprehension of an effect contradictory to the pervader, the apprehension of an effect contradictory to the effect, etc., which are different from the eleven non-apprehensions due to the difference of just a few examples.

analyzed: tāsām punar udāharaṇāni yathākramam
translated: Moreover, the examples of those are to be known in order.

analyzed: na atra dhūmaḥ tuṣāra sparśāt
translated: Here there is no smoke due to the touch of frost.

analyzed: na iha aprativaddha sāmarthyāni agni kāraṇāni santi tuṣāra sparśāt
translated: Here, the causes of fire are not present, unobstructed in their capacity, due to the touch of frost.

analyzed: na tuṣara sparśaḥ utra dhūmāt
translated: But the touch of frost is not here because of smoke.

analyzed: na iha apratibaddha sāmarthyāni śīta kāraṇāni santi dhūmāt iti  hetu kārya viruddha āpta bhāvaḥ vyāpaka kāryayoḥ
translated: Here, the causes of cold are not present, unobstructed in their capacity, because of smoke.

analyzed: viruddha kāryayoḥ anyaḥ pratiṣedhasya sādhakaḥ
translated: The presence of what is contradictory to the cause, the effect of the cause, the effect of the pervader, and the effect of what is contradictory - these are the means of negation.

analyzed: na iha dhūmaḥ hima sparśāt
translated: Here, there is no smoke due to the touch of frost, which is capable of being the cause of fire.

analyzed: na iha dhūmāt hima sparśaḥ na śakyam śīta kāraṇam iti
translated: Here, there is no touch of frost due to smoke, which is capable of being the cause of cold.

analyzed: saṅgraha ślokau
translated: The two summary verses.

original: evaṃ tāvadekena prakāreṇāsādhanāṅgavacanatvādiko nigrahasthānamiti pratipāditaṃ /🔽prakārāntareṇāpi tadevopapādayati /🔽athavetyādi na ceti samudāyaścāyamatrāvṛtyā pūrvoditārthaparityāgenārthāntarasamuccaye varttate /
analyzed: evam tāvat ekena prakāreṇa asādhana aṅga vacana tva ādikaḥ nigrahasthānam iti pratipāditam  prakāra antareṇa api tat eva upapādayati  athavā ityādi na ca iti samudāyaḥ ca ayam atra āvṛtyā pūrva udita artha parityāgena artha antara samuccaye varttate
translated: Thus far, it has been demonstrated that the fault of not stating a means of valid knowledge, etc., is a ground for defeat in one way.🔽He explains that very [fault] in another way also, with Or else, etc. And this compound na ca [means] not and, and it occurs here in the sense of a combination of a different meaning by abandoning the previously stated meaning, by repetition.

original: natu dhavasthityāthavā khadiramityādāmiva pūrvvārthaparityāgena vikalpādividhasyāpyarthasya vivakṣitatvāt /
analyzed: na tu dhava sthityā athavā khadiram ityādām iva pūrvva artha parityāgena vikalpa ādividhasya api arthasya vivakṣita tvāt
translated: But not in the sense of abandoning the previous meaning by way of the state of being a dhava or a khadira, etc., because the meaning of an option, etc., is also intended to be stated.

analyzed: iha ca paryāye sādhana śabdaḥ karana sādhanaḥ
translated: And here, in this context, the word 'proof' means the means of accomplishing.

analyzed: iha aṅga śabdaḥ avayava vacanaḥ pūrvasmin kāraṇa vacane iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: Here, the word 'part' means a component, while in the previous [context] it means a cause - this is the difference.

original: trirūpehetuvacana samudāyagrahaṇena teṣu lakṣaṇādivacanānāṃ sādhanatvaṃ tirayati /
analyzed: samudāya grahaṇena teṣu lakṣaṇa ādi vacanānām sādhana tvam tirayati
translated: By mentioning the collection of the three-featured reason, he excludes the statements of definition etc. as being proofs among them.

original: syād buddhiḥ sādharmyavati prayogenāsapakṣe hetorasatvamucyate /🔽vaidharmyavati ca na sapakṣasatvamanantarameva niṣedhyamānatvāt /
analyzed: syāt buddhiḥ sādharmyavati prayogena a sa pakṣe hetoḥ asatvam ucyate  vaidharmyavati ca na sapakṣa satvam anantaram eva niṣedhyamāna tvāt
translated: One might think that in a case of similarity, the non-existence of the reason in the dissimilar instances is stated.🔽And in a case of dissimilarity, the existence of the reason in similar instances is not stated, because it is being denied immediately after.

analyzed: tat katham tasya ekasya api avacanam asādhana aṅga vacanam iti etat na vakṣyamāṇe vyāhatam iti
translated: So how can the non-statement of even one of them be a statement of a part of the proof? This is not contradicted in what is going to be said.

analyzed: etat ca na evam eva hi vyākhyāyate
translated: And this is not explained in this way.

analyzed: tri rūpaḥ hetuḥ atha ātmakaḥ
translated: The reason is three-featured, and has a nature.

original: paramarthatovasthitastasya vacane ye prakāśake pakṣadharmavacana sapakṣasatvavacane pakṣadharmavacana vipakṣasatvavacane vā tayossamudāyaḥ
analyzed: paramarthataḥ vasthitaḥ tasya vacane ye prakāśake pakṣa dharma vacana sapakṣa satva vacane pakṣa dharma vacana vipakṣa satva vacane vā tayoḥ samudāyaḥ
translated: The statement of that which is established in the ultimate sense, the statement of the property of the subject, the statement of the existence in similar instances, or the statement of the non-existence in dissimilar instances - the collection of those two

analyzed: tasya vacana dvaya samudāyasya aṅgam pakṣadharma ādi vacanam iti pakṣadharma vat anantāvat avicalam itarayoḥ tu anyatara anyatarat kādācitkam
translated: The statement of the property of the subject, etc., is a part of that collection of two statements. Like the statement of the property of the subject, it is endless, unmoving, and the other two are sometimes one or the other.

analyzed: tena vacana dvaya samudāya rūpasya āginaḥ ṅgam dvividham eva sadā tasya idānīm aṅgasya ekasya api avacanam asādhat ṅgam vacanam
translated: Therefore, the two-fold form of the collection of two statements, which is the nature of fire, is always a part of it. Now, the non-statement of even one of those parts is a non-statement of a part of the proof.

analyzed: na kevalam dvayoḥ prathama vyākhyā anusāreṇa iti api śabdāt
translated: By the word api (even), it is not only the non-statement of two [parts] according to the first explanation.

analyzed: dvayoḥ hi a vacanam tūṣṇīmbhāvaḥ
translated: For the non-statement of two [parts] is silence.

analyzed: sa ca ukta pratibhayā tūṣṇīṃbhāvāt iti paryāya antaram api āha
translated: And that is said to be silence due to lack of presence of an answer. He also gives another synonym.

analyzed: athavā ityādi
translated: Or and so on.

analyzed: tasya eva iti tri rūpavacana samudāyasya yat na aṅgam na avayavaḥ
translated: Of that itself means of the collection of three-fold statements, that which is not a part, not a component.

analyzed: katham punar pratijñā ādīnām asādhana aṅga tvam iti ced
translated: If it is asked how the thesis, etc. are not parts of the proof,

analyzed: ucyate
translated: it is said:

original: pratijñāvacanasādhanaṃ /🔽sākṣāt pāraṃparyeṇa vā tasyāḥ siddheranutpatteḥ tathāhyartha eva pratibandhārthaṅgamayati /
analyzed: sākṣāt pāraṃparyeṇa vā tasyāḥ siddheḥ anutpatteḥ tathā hi arthaḥ eva pratibandha artham gamayati
translated: The statement of the thesis is the means of proof.🔽Because its establishment does not arise either directly or indirectly. For the meaning itself conveys the meaning of the relation,

analyzed: na abhidhānam artha pratibandha vikala tvāt
translated: not the expression, because it is devoid of the relation to the meaning.

original: tasmāt pratijñāvacanaṃ hetuvacanaṃ vā na sākṣātsādhanamarthasiddhau /🔽saṃśayaśca pakṣavacanādarthe dṛṣṭo na niścayastadatopi na sākṣāt sādhanaṃ /
analyzed: tasmāt pratijñā vacanam hetu vacanam vā na sākṣāt sādhanam artha siddhau  saṃśayaḥ ca pakṣa vacanāt arthe dṛṣṭaḥ na niścayaḥ tat atas api na sākṣāt sādhanam
translated: Therefore, the statement of the thesis or the statement of the reason is not directly a means of proof for establishing the conclusion.🔽And doubt is seen to arise regarding the meaning from the statement of the thesis, not certainty. Therefore, that too is not directly a means of proof.

analyzed: saṃśayaḥ eva asiddhaḥ pakṣa vacanāt vādi prativādinaḥ niścita tvāt atha anyeṣām bhavati
translated: It may be argued that doubt itself is not established, because the proponent and opponent are certain [of the conclusion] from the statement of the thesis, or because it arises for others.

analyzed: evam sati kṛtaka tva ādi vacane ipi avyutpaṃ
translated: If that were so, then even the statement of being produced, etc. would be useless.

analyzed: vyutpannānām saṃśayaḥ bhavati iti anekāntaḥ
translated: Because doubt arises for those who are knowledgeable, this is inconclusive.

analyzed: tat etat asaṃbaddham
translated: This is irrelevant.🔽For the proponent and opponent would be certain regarding a single property such as impermanence, or regarding a pair of contradictory properties,

original: vādiprativādinorhi niścitatvamekasmin vā dharme'nityatvādike pratyāyayitumārabdhe bhavet pratyanīkadharmadvaye vā //
analyzed: vādi prativādinoḥ hi niścita tvam ekasmin vā dharme nitya tva ādike pratyāyayitum ārabdhe bhavet pratyanīka dharma dvaye vā
translated: when one is trying to convince the other.

analyzed: na tāvat ekasmin vivāda abhāvataḥ
translated: First, not regarding a single [property], because there would be no dispute.

analyzed: sādhana prayoga ānarthakya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that the use of a proof would be pointless.

analyzed: dharma dvaye vā
translated: Or regarding a pair of properties,

analyzed: na tāvat ekasmin vivāda abhāvataḥ
translated: First, not regarding a single [property], because there would be no dispute.

analyzed: sādhana prayoga ānarthakya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that the use of a proof would be pointless.

analyzed: nā api pratyanīka dharma dvaye vastunaḥ viruddha dharma dvaya adhyāsa prasaṅgāt
translated: Nor regarding a pair of contradictory properties, because it would follow that a thing would have two contradictory properties superimposed on it.

original: yadāhyekasminvastuni pramāṇabalena viruddhau dharmau vādiprativādibhyāṃ niścitau bhavastadā tadvastu dvyātmakaṃ prāptaṃ /
analyzed: yadā hi ekasmin vastuni pramāṇa balena viruddhau dharmau vādi prativādibhyām niścitau bhavaḥ tadā tat vastu dvi ātmakam prāptam
translated: For when two contradictory properties of a single thing are ascertained by the parties through the force of a proof, then that thing becomes possessed of a dual nature.

original: atha na pramāṇasāmarthyāt tau niścitāvapi tu svasmātsvasmādāgamāt /
analyzed: atha na pramāṇa sāmarthyāt tau niścitau api tu svasmāt svasmāt āgamāt
translated: If, on the other hand, they are not ascertained through the force of a proof, but through their own scriptures,

original: evamapi tu dharmayoḥ pramāṇena niścayāt kathanna pakṣavacanāt saṃśayo bhavatīti vācyaṃ /
analyzed: evam api tu dharmayoḥ pramāṇena niścayāt katham na pakṣa vacanāt saṃśayaḥ bhavati iti vācyam
translated: then also, since the two properties are ascertained by a proof, it should be stated how doubt does not arise from the statement of the proposition.

analyzed: tasmāt pakṣa vacanam na sākṣāt sādhanam
translated: Therefore, the statement of the proposition is not directly a proof.

original: nāpi pāramparyyeṇa sādhyābhidhāyakatvenāsiddhe hetudṛṣṭāntābhāsoktivadaśakyasūcakatvāt /🔽hetuvacanantu śakyasūcakatvāt śaktitaḥ sādhananiṣṭaṃ sadocyate sādhanāṅgampratijñāvacanatve sati sādhanopakārakatvāddhetuvacanavat /
analyzed: nā api pāramparyeṇa sādhya abhidhāyaka tvena asiddhe hetu dṛṣṭānta ābhāsa ukti vat aśakya sūcaka tvāt  hetuvacanam tu śakya sūcaka tvāt śaktitaḥ sādhana niṣṭam sadā ucyate sādhana aṅgam pratijñā vacana tve sati sādhana upakāraka tvāt hetuvacana vat
translated: Nor indirectly, because it does not indicate what is to be accomplished, like the statement of a fallacious reason or example, because it cannot indicate.🔽But the statement of the reason, being able to indicate, is said to be a part of the proof, because it is related to the proof, being a statement of the proposition, because it assists the proof, like the statement of the reason.

analyzed: sādhana viṣaya prakāśana dvāreṇa ca pratijñā sādhanam anugṛhṇāti
translated: And it assists the proof of the proposition by revealing the subject of the proof.

analyzed: anyathā hi aviṣayam tat sādhanam pravarttate
translated: For otherwise, the proof would proceed without a subject.

analyzed: jñāna ātma manaḥ sannikarṣa ādīnām api sādhana upakāraka tvam atas vacana tve sati iti viśeṣaṇam
translated: The qualification when it is a statement is added to indicate that knowledge, self, mind, contact, etc. are also aids to the means of knowledge.

analyzed: itas ca sādhana aṅga sādhya sādhana viṣaya prakāśanāt dṛsṭānta vacana vat iti
translated: And for this reason also, because it illuminates the means of knowledge, the subsidiary, the object to be accomplished, and the means of accomplishment, it is like a statement of an example.

analyzed: idam api atyartham asāram
translated: This too is extremely pointless.

original: yasmādanityaṃ śabdaṃ sādhayetyabhyarthanā bāhyaṃ vacanatve sati sādhanopakārakaṃ sādhyasādhakaviparyayaprakāśakañcana ca tadantaraṅgaṃ sādhyasiddhāvāṅgaṃ
analyzed: yasmāt anityam śabdam sādhaya iti abhyarthanā bāhyam vacana tve sati sādhana upakārakam sādhya sādhaka viparyaya prakāśakam cana ca tat antaraṅgam sādhya siddhau āṅgam
translated: Because the request to prove that sound is non-eternal is external, when it is a statement, it aids the means of knowledge and illuminates the opposite of the means of accomplishment and what is to be accomplished, and that is internal. When the object to be accomplished is accomplished, it is a subsidiary.

original: ko vā viṣayopadarśanasyopayogo yadi hyanena vinā na sādhyasiddhiḥ syāt /
analyzed: kaḥ vā viṣaya upadarśanasya upayogaḥ yadi hi anena vinā na sādhya siddhiḥ syāt
translated: Or what is the use of indicating the object? If without this the accomplishment of what is to be accomplished would not occur,

analyzed: sarvva sobheta
translated: then everything would be proper.

original: pakṣadharmānvayavyatirekatadvacanasāmarthyācca pratīyate tasmādanitya evetyevamādinā punaḥ sisādhayiṣitorthaḥ prathamasādhyāpekṣayā vyāpakaviruddhopalabdhirdvitīyasādhyāpekṣayā
analyzed: pakṣa dharma anvaya vyatireka tad vacana sāmarthyāt ca pratīyate tasmāt anityaḥ eva iti evamādinā punar sisādhayiṣita ūrthaḥ prathama sādhya apekṣayā vyāpaka viruddha upalabdhiḥ dvitīya sādhya apekṣayā
translated: And because the property of the subject, the positive and negative concomitance, and the statement of that are understood, the object to be proved again, such as Therefore it is impermanent, etc., is contradictory to the pervader in relation to the second probandum,

analyzed: ca svabhāva hetuḥ  atas eva nigamanasya avyāpaka viruddha upalabdhiḥ dvitīya sādhya apekṣayā ca svabhā ahetuḥ
translated: and is a reason based on the nature of the thing.🔽For this very reason, the statement of the conclusion is not a separate part, because the statement of the reason is itself the statement of the conclusion.

analyzed: atas eva nigamanasya avayava antara tva pratipādanāya uktāḥ hetavaḥ siddhāḥ
translated: For this very reason, the reasons that have been stated to establish that the statement of the conclusion is a separate part are unestablished.

analyzed: tat api etena eva pratyuktam yat āha

analyzed: pratyayekṣa  pratijñā ādīn vākya artha pratipattaye

analyzed: procyamānat nigamanam punar uktat na jāyate

analyzed: viprakīrṇaiḥ ca vacanaiḥ na ekaḥ arthaḥ pratipādyate
translated: And a single meaning is not conveyed by scattered words.

analyzed: tena sambandha sidhi artham vācyat nigamanam pṛthak

analyzed: iti alam ati prasāriṇyā kathayā

analyzed: anvaya vyatirekayoḥ vā iti paryyāya antara kathanam upādānam iti nyā sū
translated: The method of stating other alternatives is mentioned as upādāna in the Nyā. sū.

analyzed: vartate dvitīyasya asāmarthyam jātāyāḥ siddheḥ punar ajanya tvāt
translated: The second one is powerless, because the established thing that has arisen is not produced again.

analyzed: pramāṇasamuccaya ṭīkākārāḥ tu āhuḥ nanu ityādi
translated: But the commentators on the Pramaṇa-samuccaya say But is it not so? and so on.

analyzed: na ityādi uttaraḥ

analyzed: yadi ca iti upacaya hetuḥ
translated: If it is is the reason for the increase.

original: sādhanāvayavaḥ pratijñāṃ prāpnoti niyamena sādhyapratītinimittatvāt pakṣadharmādivacanavat /
analyzed: sādhana avayavaḥ pratijñām prāpnoti niyamena sādhya pratīti nimitta tvāt pakṣa dharma ādi vacana vat
translated: The part of the proof obtains the thesis, because it is the cause of the cognition of the probandum, like the statement of the property of the subject and so on.

analyzed: sandigdha vyatirekaḥ hetuḥ iti ced āha
translated: If it is said that the reason is inconclusive when the vyatireka is doubtful, he says:

analyzed: nahi pakṣa dharma vacanasya api iti

analyzed: tat tulyam iti viruddha anaikāntikayoḥ pakṣa dharma sadbhāve pi agamaka tvāt

analyzed: tatas eva saṃsayaḥ

translated: If it is said that the statement of the property of the subject is not a proof because doubt arises from the statement of the common and other reasons, he says:

analyzed: etat eva vyanakti pakṣa dharma vacanāt api iti

original: tadanenānantarasya hetorvyabhicāraṅkathayati /🔽nanu ca pakṣadharmasya śrāvaṇatvāderapradarśite sambandhenaiva sādhanāvayavatvamato vipakṣatvābhāvānna vyabhicāraḥ /
analyzed: tat anena anantarasya hetoḥ vyabhicāram kathayati  nanu ca pakṣa dharmasya śrāvaṇa tva ādeḥ apradarśite sambandhena eva sādhana avayavatvam atas vipakṣa tva abhāvāt na vyabhicāraḥ
translated: By this he shows the fallacy of the immediately following reason.🔽But isn't it so that audibility, which is the property of the subject, is a part of the proof even without a demonstrated relation? Therefore, because it is not the counter-example, there is no fallacy.

analyzed: evam manyate

analyzed: pakṣa vacane api tulyam etat iti tat api sādhanam syāt

But for us,🔽The statement The statement of what is to be inferred is considered to be about the meaning of the reason
