translated: But when the conjunction of wood and leaves ceases, sound is heard by someone standing far away at the time of disjunction. This is the manifestation of sound, which passes beyond the time of conjunction and becomes due to conjunction.

analyzed: kāraṇa abhāvāt hi kārya abhāvaḥ iti
translated: Because the absence of an effect is due to the absence of a cause.

analyzed: nanu ayam anaikāntikaḥ eva
translated: But this is not a valid reason, because it is subject to the fallacy of postulation of what is past.

analyzed: saṃyoga vyaṃgya tvāt iti
translated: Because it is manifested by conjunction.

original: anityamapi saṃyogena vyajyamānaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā ghaṭa iti / na /
analyzed: anityam api saṃyogena vyajyamānam dṛṣṭam yathā ghaṭaḥ iti na
translated: It is seen that even what is impermanent is manifested by conjunction, like a pot. No.

original: saṃyoga vyaṃgyatvenāvasthānasya sādhyatvānna brūmo nityaḥ śabda iti /
analyzed: saṃyoga vyaṃgya tvena avasthānasya sādhya tvāt na brūmaḥ nityaḥ śabdaḥ iti
translated: Because the probandum is the persistence as manifested by conjunction, we do not say that sound is eternal.

original: api tvavatiṣṭhate śabda ityayaṃ pratijñārthastadā ca saṃyogavyaṃgyatvādityayaṃ heturanaikāntiko na hyanavasthitaṃ kiñcitsaṃyogenābhivyajyamānaḥ
analyzed: api tu avatiṣṭhate śabdaḥ iti ayam pratijñā arthaḥ tadā ca saṃyoga vyaṃgya tvāt iti ayam hetuḥ anaikāntikaḥ na hi anavasthitam kiñcid saṃyogena abhivyajyamānaḥ  /
translated: But if the meaning of the proposition is that the sound persists, then the reason because it is manifested by conjunction is inconclusive, for nothing that is not permanent is manifested by conjunction.

original: kathamiti tadanena prakāreṇa saṃyogavyaṅgyatvameva śabdasya pratiṣiddhyata iti nāyamasiddhād vyāvartate /
analyzed: katham iti tat anena prakāreṇa saṃyoga vyaṅgya tvam eva śabdasya pratiṣiddhyataḥ iti na ayam asiddhāt vyāvartate
translated: How? In this way, the manifestation of sound by conjunction is itself being refuted, so this [reason] does not avoid being unestablished.

original: anyathāneyaṃ śabdasya vyaktiḥ saṃyogikālamatyetīti na saṃyoganimittā bhavatīti /
analyzed: anyathā anā iyam śabdasya vyaktiḥ saṃyogi kālam atyeti iti na saṃyoga nimittā bhavati iti
translated: Otherwise, this manifestation of sound would transcend the time of conjunction, so it would not be caused by conjunction.

analyzed: vacanasya kaḥ ṛthaḥ iti vaktavyam
translated: The meaning of the statement should be stated.

analyzed: syāt buddhiḥ sarvadā adharmiṇī a vidyamānasya asiddha tvam
translated: The idea might be that the unestablished is always in the subject.

original: ayantu na sarvathā dharmiṇyasiddho yenotpattikāle saṃyogavyaṅgyatvamasti /
analyzed: na sarvathā dharmiṇī asiddhaḥ yena utpatti kāle saṃyoga vyaṅgya tvam asti
translated: But this [sound] is not completely unestablished in the subject, since at the time of its origination there is manifestation by conjunction.

analyzed: na tu upalabdhi kāle iti
translated: But not at the time of perception.

analyzed: tat uktam
translated: That has been said.

analyzed: eka deśa asiddhasya api asiddha ttda parijñānāt
translated: Because even when a part is unestablished, the unestablished nature is recognized.

analyzed: yathā nityāḥ paramāṇave gandhava tvāt
translated: For example, atoms are permanent because they have smell.

analyzed: śveta nāḥ ca taravaḥ svāpāt iti
translated: And trees are conscious because they sleep.

original: yaścānityaḥ śabda iti pratijānīte sa kuṭhāradārusaṃyogādeḥ śabdasyotpattimeva pratipadyate /
analyzed: yaḥ ca anityaḥ śabdaḥ iti pratijānīte sa kuṭhāra dāru saṃyoga ādeḥ śabdasya utpattim eva pratipadyate
translated: And one who asserts that sound is impermanent understands the production of sound from the conjunction of axe and wood.

analyzed: na punar avasthitasya abhivyaktam iti vyaktam asya anyatara asiddha tvam
translated: But it is not the manifestation of what exists. Thus its other-unprovenness is clear.

original: atha saṃyoge satyupalabdheriti hetvarthābhyupagamān nāyamasiddho heturiti samādhīyate /
analyzed: atha saṃyoge sati upalabdheḥ iti hetvartha abhyupagamāt na ayam asiddhaḥ hetuḥ iti samādhīyate
translated: But if it is accepted that the meaning of the reason is because it is perceived when there is conjunction, then this reason is not unproven.

original: tathāpi tailatejovarttisaṃyoge kulālamṛtpiṇḍadaṇḍasaṃyoge ca sati dīpaghaṭādayaḥ samupalabhyante /🔽na ca teṣāntatra saṃyogāprāptyavasthānamityanenānaikāntika eva prāpnotīti na kālātītaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api taila tejaḥ vartti saṃyoge kulāla mṛd piṇḍa daṇḍa saṃyoge ca sati dīpa ghaṭa ādayaḥ samupalabhyante  na ca teṣām tatra saṃyoga aprāpti avasthānam iti anena anaikāntikaḥ eva prāpnoti iti na kāla atītaḥ
translated: Even so, when there is conjunction of oil, light, and wick, and of potter, clay, and stick, lamps and pots are perceived.🔽And they do not remain in a state of non-arrival at conjunction. Thus it would only be inconclusive, not beyond time.

analyzed: tad uttara kālam api avasthāne sādhye samudāya antara vyaya
translated: If it is to be proven that they remain even after that, there is destruction of another aggregate.

analyzed: vādinaḥ viruddhaḥ
translated: For the proponent, it is contradictory.

analyzed: sapakṣa abhāvāt eva tatra vatteḥ abhāvāt  kṣaṇa sthiti dharmavati ca dharmiṇi
translated: Because of the absence of the reason there, due to the absence of a similar instance.🔽And in the case of a subject that has the property of momentary existence,

analyzed: rūpa ādike vidyamāna tvāt
translated: because it exists in the form, etc.

analyzed: sthira bhāva vādinaḥ tu prati pratibandha vaikalyam sādhana vaiphalyam ca
translated: But for one who advocates the doctrine of permanent existence, the deficiency of the counter-agent and the futility of the proof.

original: anaṅgīkṛtasiddhānte tu nyāyavādini prativādini pūrvapakṣapratipādito doṣa iti /
analyzed: an aṅgīkṛta siddhānte tu nyāya vādini prativādini pūrvapakṣa pratipāditaḥ doṣaḥ iti
translated: But when the disputant does not accept the established conclusion, the fault stated in the prima facie view of the opponent is [the fault of the disputant].

analyzed: evam udāharaṇa antare api dūṣaṇam utprekṣya vaktavyam iti
translated: In the same way, the refutation should be imagined and stated in other examples as well.

analyzed: yasmāt prakaraṇa cintā sa nirṇṇaya artham apadiṣṭaḥ prakaranasamaḥ
translated: Since the consideration of the topic is for the purpose of determining it, it is called similar to the topic.

analyzed: nyā sū
translated: Nyā. Sū.

original: vimarśādhiṣṭhānau pakṣapratipakṣāvanavasitau prakaraṇantasya cintāmavimarśāt prabhṛti prāṅnirṇṇayāt parīkṣaṇaṃ sā yatra kṛtā sa nirṇṇayārthaṃ
analyzed: vimarśa adhiṣṭhānau pakṣa pratipakṣau anavasitau cintām avimarśāt prabhṛti prāk nirṇṇayāt parīkṣaṇam sā yatra kṛtā sa nirṇṇaya artham
translated: The topic is the undecidable state of the two sides, the prima facie view and the counter-view, which are the basis of deliberation, from the beginning of deliberation up to the determination. The consideration of it is the examination done there. It is for the purpose of determining it.

original: prayuktobhayapakṣasāmyāt prakaraṇamanativarttamānaḥ prakaraṇasamo na nirṇṇayāya kalpyate /
analyzed: prayukta ubhaya pakṣa sāmyāt prakaraṇam an ativarttamānaḥ prakaraṇasamaḥ na nirṇṇayāya kalpyate
translated: Since it does not go beyond the topic due to the equality of both sides employed, it is called similar to the topic. It is not considered for determination.

analyzed: kasmāt punar prakaraṇa cintā tattva apalabdheḥ
translated: Why is the consideration of the topic for the apprehension of the truth?

original: yasmādupalabdhetatverthe nivarttate cintā tasmātsāmānyenādhigatasya yā viśeṣato'nupalabdhiḥ sā prakaraṇacintāṃ prayojayatīti /
analyzed: yasmāt nivarttate cintā tasmāt sāmānyena adhigatasya yā viśeṣataḥ anupalabdhiḥ sā prakaraṇa cintām prayojayati iti
translated: Because the consideration ceases when the truth is apprehended. Therefore, the non-apprehension of a particular of what is generally apprehended gives rise to the consideration of the topic.

analyzed: udāharaṇam anityaḥ śabdaḥ nitya dharma anupalabdheḥ
translated: For example, sound is impermanent because of the non-apprehension of eternal properties.

analyzed: an upalabhyamāna nitya dharmakam anitya ndṛṣṭam sthālī ādi
translated: The impermanent is seen in a pot, etc., where the permanent property is not perceived.

original: yatra samāno dharmaḥ saṃśayakāraṇahetutvenopādīyate saṃśayasamaḥ savyabhicāra eva /
analyzed: yatra samānaḥ dharmaḥ saṃśaya kāraṇa hetu tvena upādīyate saṃśayasamaḥ savyabhicāraḥ eva
translated: The similar doubt is when a common property is accepted as the cause of doubt, but it is actually inconclusive.

original: yā tu vimarśasya viśeṣāpekṣatobhayapakṣaviśeṣānupalabdhau sā prakaraṇampravartayati /
analyzed: yā tu vimarśasya viśeṣa apekṣatā ubhaya pakṣa viśeṣa anupalabdhau sā prakaraṇam pravartayati
translated: But when there is doubt about the specific features of both alternatives due to the absence of the perception of specific features, that gives rise to a discussion.

original: yathā ca śabde nityadharmo nopalabhyate tathānityadharmopi /
analyzed: yathā ca śabde nitya dharmaḥ na upalabhyate tathā anitya dharmaḥ api
translated: And just as the permanent property is not perceived in sound, so too the impermanent property.

analyzed: sā iyam ubhaya pakṣa viśeṣa anupalabdhiḥ prakaraṇa cintām prayojayati katham viparyaye prakaraṇa nivṛtteḥ
translated: This non-perception of specific features of both alternatives gives rise to a discussion, as to how the discussion would cease if the opposite were the case.

analyzed: yadi nitya dharmaḥ śabde gṛhyeta na syāt prakaraṇam
translated: If the permanent property were grasped in sound, there would be no discussion.

original: yadi na nityadharmo gṛhyeta evamapi nivarttate prakaranaṃ /
analyzed: yadi na nitya dharmaḥ gṛhyeta evam api nivarttate prakaranam
translated: If the permanent property were not grasped, then too the discussion would cease.

original: soyaṃ hetu rubhau pakṣau pravarttayannānyatarasya nirṇṇayāya kalpyata iti /
analyzed: saḥ uyam hetu rubhau pakṣau pravarttayan na anyatarasya nirṇṇayāya kalpyate iti
translated: This reason, giving rise to both alternatives, is not accepted for the purpose of determining either one.

analyzed: na tu ayam sādhya a viśiṣṭaḥ eva
translated: But this is not just the same as the conclusion to be established.

analyzed: na a viśiṣṭaḥ
translated: It is not the same.

analyzed: tasya eva prakaraṇa pravṛtti hetoḥ dharmasya hetu tvena upādānāt
translated: Because the very property that is the cause of the discussion is accepted as the reason.

original: yatra sādhyena samāno dharmo hetutvenopādīyate sa sādhyāviśiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: yatra sādhyena samānaḥ dharmaḥ hetu tvena upādīyate sa sādhya aviśiṣṭaḥ
translated: Where a property similar to the probandum is adduced as the reason, that is the probandum-indistinguishable.

original: yatra punaḥ prakaraṇa pravṛttihetureva sa prakaraṇasama iti /
analyzed: yatra punar prakaraṇa pravṛtti hetuḥ eva sa prakaraṇasamaḥ iti
translated: And where the very reason for the occurrence of the context is [the probandum], that is the context-similar.

analyzed: atra api nitya anitya dharma anupalambha dvayāt eva prakaraṇa cintā
translated: Here too, the consideration of the context is from the non-apprehension of both permanent and impermanent properties,

analyzed: na tu ekasmāt
translated: not from one alone.

analyzed: viparyaye prakaraṇa nivṛttiḥ iti vacanāt
translated: Because it is said that the cessation of the context is in the opposite case.

analyzed: tat yadi nitya anidya dharma anupalabdheḥ iti hetuḥ syāt
translated: If that were the reason, from the non-apprehension of permanent and impermanent properties,

analyzed: syāt prakaraṇasamaḥ
translated: it would be context-similar.

analyzed: tad eka dharma anupalabdheḥ tu upādāne katham prakaraṇasamaḥ iti abhidhānīyam
translated: But when only one property is adduced, how can it be called context-similar?

analyzed: ubhaya dharma anupalambha upādāne api sapakṣa vipakṣayoḥ anuvṛtti vyāvṛtyoḥ aniścayāt asādharaṇa anaikāntikaḥ bhavati iti katham asya hetvābhāsaḥ
translated: Even when the non-apprehension of both properties is adduced, it becomes a non-exclusive reason due to the uncertainty of concomitance and non-concomitance in similar and dissimilar instances. How can it be a fallacy of the reason?

analyzed: sa antara tvam
translated: [It is a fallacy] because of having an interval.

analyzed: bhavatu nāma eka dharma anupalabdhiḥ eva hetuḥ prakaraṇasamaḥ
translated: Let it be that the reason from the non-apprehension of only one property is context-similar.

original: tathāpi nityaśabdavādyavaśyameva vyāmohānnityadharmān pratipadyata iti prativādyasiddhīyaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tathā api nitya śabda vādī avaśyam eva vyāmohāt nitya dharmān pratipadyate iti prativādyasiddhīyam bhavati
translated: Even so, the proponent of the word permanent must necessarily understand permanent properties due to delusion. Thus, it becomes a fallacy of the probandum being unestablished for the opponent.

analyzed: atha pramāṇena nitya dharmma pratikṣepāt nitya dharma anupalabdhiḥ pratipādyate
translated: Now, if it is being taught that the non-apprehension of eternal properties is due to the contradiction of eternal properties by a valid means of knowledge,

original: tadāpi niścāyakatvāt samyajjñānaheturevāyaṃ iti kathaṃ hetvābhāsaḥ prakaraṇasamaḥ /
analyzed: tadā api niścāyaka tvāt samyak jñāna hetuḥ eva ayam iti katham hetvābhāsaḥ prakaraṇasamaḥ
translated: then even in that case, since it ascertains, it is indeed the cause of right knowledge. So how can it be a fallacious reason, similar to the subject?

analyzed: tadā hi viśeṣa upalabdhiḥ eva hetvarthaḥ vyavatiṣṭhate
translated: For then, the meaning of the reason is indeed determined as the apprehension of a specific property.

analyzed: viśeṣāḥ ca nityasya kṛtaka tva ādayaḥ
translated: And the specific properties of the eternal are being produced, etc.

original: na ca tatkṛtā prakaraṇacintā viparyaye prakaraṇanivṛtteriti vacanāt /
analyzed: na ca tad kṛtā prakaraṇa cintā viparyaye prakaraṇa nivṛtteḥ iti vacanāt
translated: And the consideration of the context is not done by that, because of the statement in the case of the opposite, the cessation of the context.

original: api ca nityadharmānupalabdheriti kimayaṃ prasajyapratiṣedhaḥ kimvā pratiyogividhānaṃ /🔽yadi prasajyapratiṣedhastadā prameyatvādivat sādhāraṇānaikāntikoyaṃ nityadharmopalabdhiḥ pratiṣedhamātrasyānityatvarahiteṣvasatsvapi sambhavāt
analyzed: api ca nitya dharma anupalabdheḥ iti kim ayam prasajya pratiṣedhaḥ kim vā pratiyogi vidhānam  yadi prasajya pratiṣedhaḥ tadā prameya tva ādi vat sādhāraṇa anaikāntikaḥ yam nitya dharma upalabdhiḥ pratiṣedha mātrasya anitya tva rahiteṣu asatsu api sambhavāt
translated: Moreover, what is meant by the non-apprehension of eternal properties? Is it a negative without an implicative, or is it an implicative negation?🔽If it is a negative without an implicative, then this non-apprehension of eternal properties is a common and inconclusive reason, like being an object of knowledge, because the mere negation exists even in non-eternal things that lack non-eternality.

analyzed: atha yuktyā hetu pratirūpa tva ayogaḥ
translated: If it is an implicative negation, then even in that case, due to the reasoning stated just before, it is not suitable to be a counter-reason.

analyzed: anyaḥ tu anyathā idam sūtra dvayam vyācaṣṭe
translated: However, another person explains these two sūtras differently.

analyzed: yaḥ hetuḥ hetu kāla ipad iṣṭā utyeti apaiti
translated: The reason that is stated at the time of the reason, that passes away, goes away,

analyzed: kasmāt apaiti
translated: Why does it fail?

original: pratyakṣeṇāgamena ubhayena vā pīḍyamānaḥ sa kālamatīta iti kālātīta ityucyate /
analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa āgamena ubhayena vā pīḍyamānaḥ sa kālam atītaḥ iti kāla atītaḥ iti ucyate
translated: It is said to be beyond time when it is contradicted by perception, scripture, or both, and the time has passed.

original: kutaḥ punaḥ pratyakṣāgamavirodho labhyata iti cet /
analyzed: kutas punar pratyakṣa āgama virodhaḥ labhyate iti ced
translated: If it is asked how contradiction by perception and scripture is obtained,

original: caturlakṣaṇo heturiti vacanāt /🔽tathāhi pūrvavaccheṣavatsāmānyato dṛṣṭanyā / sū / / /
analyzed: catur lakṣaṇaḥ hetuḥ iti vacanāt  tathā hi pūrvavat śeṣavat sāmānyatas
translated: it is because it is said that the reason has four characteristics.

analyzed: ñca iti atra catur rūpaḥ hetuḥ iṣṭaḥ
translated: For thus, the reason is accepted as having four aspects in the statement like before, like the remainder, seen in common, etc.
Like before means the pervader of what is to be proven.

analyzed: śeṣavat iti
translated: Like the remainder means it exists in what is similar to that.

analyzed: sāmānyatas ca dṛṣṭam ca śabdāt aviruddham ca iti
translated: Seen in common and not contradicted by scripture are also [reasons].

original: tathā bhāṣyavacanamapyasti /🔽yatpunaranumānaṃ pratyakṣāgamaviruddhaṃ nyāyābhāsaḥ sa iti /
analyzed: tathā bhāṣya vacanam api asti  yat punar anumānam pratyakṣa āgama viruddham nyāya ābhāsaḥ saḥ iti
translated: There is also a statement in the commentary like this.🔽But inference contradicted by perception and scripture is fallacious reasoning.

original: tadevaṃ trairūpye sati pratyakṣāgamābhyāṃ yo vādhyate sa kālātyayāpadiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: tat evam trairūpye sati pratyakṣa āgamābhyām yaḥ vādhyate sa kāla atyaya apadiṣṭaḥ
translated: Thus, when it has three aspects, that which is contradicted by perception and scripture is beyond time.

original: sa ca tridhā bhidyate pratyakṣaviruddha āgamaviruddha ubhayaviruddhaśceti /
analyzed: sa ca tridhā bhidyate pratyakṣa viruddhaḥ āgama viruddhaḥ ubhaya viruddhaḥ ca iti
translated: And it is divided into three types: contradicted by perception, contradicted by scripture, and contradicted by both.

analyzed: pratyakṣa viruddhaḥ yathā anuṣṇa agniḥ dravya tvāt udaka vat
translated: Contradicted by perception is like fire is not hot because it is a substance, like water.

original: āgamaviruddho yathā brāhmaṇena surā pātavyā dravatvāt kṣiravat /
analyzed: āgama viruddhaḥ yathā brāhmaṇena surā pātavyā drava tvāt kṣira vat
translated: Contradictory to scripture is like, Wine should be drunk by a Brahmin because it is a liquid, like milk.

analyzed: ubhaya viruddhaḥ yathā raśmivat cakṣuḥ indriya tvāt ghrāṇa ādi vat iti
translated: Contradictory to both is like, The eye sense faculty is not radiant because it is a sense faculty, like the nose sense faculty.

original: na cāyaṃ kila pakṣavirodhaḥ pakṣavirodhasya pratikṣepāditi /
analyzed: na ca ayam kila pakṣa virodhaḥ pakṣa virodhasya pratikṣepāt iti
translated: And this is not a contradiction with the thesis, because the contradiction with the thesis is rejected.

analyzed: tat etat trairupya lakṣaṇa anavavodha vaiśadyam
translated: This is the lack of clarity in understanding the definition of the three characteristics.

original: trairūpyaṃ hi yadā svaṃ pramāṇaiḥ pariniścitaṃ pakṣadharmatvādikaṃ trayaṃ ca yatra bādhyā tatra pratibandhosti /
analyzed: trairūpyam hi yadā svam pramāṇaiḥ pariniścitam pakṣa dharma tva ādikam trayam ca yatra bādhyā tatra pratibandhaḥ usti
translated: For the three characteristics of being a property of the subject and so on, which are well-established by the means of valid cognition, and which are to be contradicted, there is an invariable relation where they occur.

original: bādhāvinābhāvayorvirodhāt /🔽avinābhāvo hi satyeva sādhyadharme hetorbhāvaḥ kathañcāsau tallakṣaṇo dharmiṇi hetuḥ syānna cātra sādhyadharma ityādikamatrābādhitaviṣayatvadūṣaṇānusāreṇa
analyzed: bādhā vinābhāvayoḥ virodhāt  avinābhāvaḥ hi sati eva sādhya dharme hetoḥ bhāvaḥ katham ca asau tad lakṣaṇaḥ dharmiṇi hetuḥ syāt na ca atra sādhya dharmaḥ iti ādikam atra abādhita viṣayatva dūṣaṇa anusāreṇa
translated: Because contradiction and invariable relation are mutually exclusive.

analyzed: vaktavyam
translated: For invariable relation is the existence of the reason when the property to be proved exists. And how can that be a reason on the subject with the characteristic of the property to be proved, when there is no property to be proved here? And so on, should be stated according to the criticism of unobstructed object in this case.

original: yatra punariyaṃ bādhodāhṛtā na teṣāṃ trailakṣaṇyaṃ manāgapyasti pratibandhavaikalyāt /
analyzed: yatra punar iyam bādhā udāhṛtā na teṣām trailakṣaṇyam manāk api asti pratibandha vaikalyāt
translated: Where this contradiction is cited, they do not have even the slightest three characteristics, due to the lack of relation.

analyzed: abhyupagata pakṣa prayogasya ca pakṣa doṣaḥ eva ayam yuktaḥ
translated: And this is rightly a fault of the thesis for the application of the accepted thesis.

analyzed: yat punar bahu asaṃbaddham udgrāhitam tat atyantam asāram iti na iha avasīyate  /
translated: But what has been extensively and irrelevantly set forth to avoid the faults of the thesis is utterly pointless, so it is not considered here.

analyzed: yasmāt prakaraṇa cintā iti prakaranam bhāṣye nirūpitam
translated: Because the topic is considered in the context, the context is determined in the commentary.

analyzed: tasya udāharaṇam
translated: An example of that is:

analyzed: aṇuḥ aṇu antara kārya tvam pratipadyate na vā iti cintāyām kaścid abhidhatte
translated: The atom is considered to be the effect of another atom or not. Someone says this.

original: aṇuraṇvantarakāryo rūpādimatvāt taddvyaṇukādivaditi /🔽yosāvaṇoraṇuḥ kāraṇatvenopādīyate tatrāpi rūpādimatvamastīti cintā kimiyaṃ rūpādimatvādaṇvantarakāryo na veti cintāyāñca yadi tasyāpyṇvantarakāryatvaṃ
analyzed: aṇuḥ aṇu antara kāryaḥ rūpa ādima tvāt tat dvyaṇuka ādi vat iti  yaḥ asau aṇoḥ aṇuḥ kāraṇa tvena upādīyate tatra api rūpa ādima tvam asti iti cintā kim iyam rūpa ādima tvāt aṇu antara kāryaḥ na vā iti cintāyām ca yadi tasya api ṇu antara kārya tvam
translated: The atom is the effect of another atom because it has form, etc., like the dyad atom and so on.

original: rūpādimatvāditi vakti tadā tasyāpi rūpādimatvamastīti punarapi cintā tadevamanavasthārūpaṃ prakaraṇaṃ pravarttayatīti prakaraṇasama ityucyate
analyzed: rūpa ādima tvāt iti vakti tadā tasya api rūpa ādima tvam asti iti punar api cintā tat evam anavasthā rūpam prakaraṇam pravarttayati iti prakaraṇasamaḥ iti ucyate
translated: In that atom which is accepted as a cause, there is also form, etc. The consideration is whether this is the effect of another atom or not. And in the consideration of whether it has form, etc., if he says that it is the effect of another atom because it has form, etc., then it has form, etc., so the consideration continues again. Thus, the context proceeds in the form of an infinite regress, so it is called the context-fallacy.

original: athāṇuraṇvantarakāryatvaṃ na pratipadyate rūpādimatve sati tadānaikāntiko heturiti tasmād bhidyate'naikāntikāt prakaraṇasamaḥ /
analyzed: atha aṇuḥ aṇu antara kārya tvam na pratipadyate rūpa ādima tve sati tadā anaikāntikaḥ hetuḥ iti tasmāt bhidyate naikāntikāt prakaraṇasamaḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, the atom does not produce another atom, then the reason is inconclusive, because it is present in the dissimilar class. Therefore, the prakarana-sama is distinguished from the inconclusive by this.

analyzed: na ca ayam viruddhaḥ viparyaya sādhaka tvāt  na asiddhaḥ pakṣa dharma tva darśanāt
translated: And this is not contradictory, because it proves the opposite.🔽It is not unestablished, because the property of the subject is shown.

analyzed: na kāla atyaya apadiṣṭaḥ pratyakṣa āgamābhyām a bādhyamāna tvāt
translated: It is not contradicted by time, because it is not contradicted by perception and scripture.

analyzed: atas ṛtha antaram iti
translated: Therefore, it is a different case.

analyzed: athavā pradeśe karaṇam prakaraṇam ca iti kāraṇa siddhiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Or, the place is the cause, and the context is the reason. This is the meaning of the establishment of the cause.

original: pradeśe siddhiritīyaṃ cintā yasmāddhetorapadiṣṭā bhavati sa prakaraṇasamaḥ sa pradeśasādhakatvāt samaḥ /
analyzed: pradeśe siddhiḥ iti iyam cintā yasmāt hetoḥ apadiṣṭā bhavati sa prakaraṇasamaḥ sa pradeśa sādhaka tvāt samaḥ
translated: The thought that the establishment is in the place is called prakarana-sama because it is equal to the establishment of the place.

analyzed: yathā eka deśe sādhaka tvam tathā itaratra api iti asādhaka tva sāmānyāt samaḥ
translated: Just as it is not a proof in one part, so it is in the other also. Therefore, it is equal due to the commonality of non-proof.

analyzed: tasmāt eka deśa varttī dharmaḥ prakaraṇasamaḥ
translated: Therefore, a property that exists in one part is prakarana-sama.

analyzed: tat yathā pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyu ākāśāni anityāni sattāva tvāt iti
translated: For example, earth, water, fire, air, and space are impermanent because they exist.

analyzed: atrā api yadi akṣapāda mata anusārī tāvat evam pramāṇayati
translated: Here also, if one argues in this way following the philosophy of Akṣapāda, then thus he argues.

original: paramāṇuḥ paramāṇvantarapūrvvako rūpādimatvād dvyaṇukādivaditi tadā tasyābhyupetavirodha iti nāyamatītakālād bhidyate /
analyzed: paramāṇuḥ paramāṇu antara pūrvvakaḥ rūpa ādima tvāt dvyaṇuka ādi vat iti tadā tasya abhyupeta virodhaḥ iti na ayam atīta kālāt bhidyate
translated: If the atom is preceded by another atom, it has form, etc., like a dyad, etc. Then there is contradiction with what is accepted. Therefore, this is not different from the past time.

analyzed: atha bauddhaḥ karoti
translated: Now, if the Buddhist argues,

analyzed: tadā api hetoḥ asiddhiḥ paramāṇūnām rūpa ādi vyatirekeṇa anabhyupagamāt
translated: even then the reason is unestablished, because atoms are not accepted as separate from form, etc.

analyzed: ayogāt ca dvi adīnām ca abhāvāt ubhaya vikalaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: And because dyads and so on are impossible, the example lacks both.

original: yadāpyanapekṣitasiddhānto nyāyavādī brūte tadāpi dvitīyapakṣoditadoṣānivṛttiriti nāyamasiddhādvyāvarttate /
analyzed: yadā api anapekṣita siddhāntaḥ nyāyavādī brūte tadā api dvitīya pakṣa udita doṣa anivṛttiḥ iti na ayam asiddhāt vyāvarttate
translated: Even when the logician speaks without regard for established doctrine, the faults stated in the second view still persist. Therefore, this does not exclude the unestablished.

original: yo'panumeyaikadeśavarttī dharmaḥ pṛthivyādīnyanityānigandhavatvāditi ayamapyapasiddhāntāntarbhūta eveti na pṛthagvācyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ upanumeya eka deśa varttī dharmaḥ pṛthivī ādīni anityāni gandhava tvāt iti ayam api apasiddhānta antarbhūtaḥ eva iti na pṛthak vācyaḥ
translated: As for the argument that things like earth are impermanent because they have smell, which is a property of only a part of the inferable, this too is included within the fallacy of unestablished basis and need not be stated separately.

analyzed: na asiddhaḥ pakṣa eka deśa dharma tvāt
translated: It is not unestablished, because it is a property of only a part of the subject.

analyzed: sapakṣa eka deśa vartti vat iti ced viṣamaḥ yam upanyāsaḥ
translated: If it is argued that it is like being present in only a part of the similar instance, this presentation is flawed.

original: sapakṣa eva ca satvamityatra hi samuccīyamānāvadhāraṇameva na sakalasapakṣadharmatāṃ sādhanasya pratipādayati /
analyzed: sapakṣe eva ca satvam iti atra hi samuccīyamāna avadhāraṇam eva na sakala sapakṣa dharmatām sādhanasya pratipādayati
translated: For in the statement and being present only in the similar instance, the mere ascertainment of the combination does not convey that the reason is present in all similar instances.

original: anumeye satvavacanaṃ punarayogavyavacchedena niyantṛbhūtamaśeṣasādhyadharmidharmatāyāḥ pratipādakamityanenaiva pakṣaikadeśāsiddhabhedānāmapohaḥ
analyzed: anumeye sattva vacanam punar ayoga vyavacchedena niyantṛ bhūtam aśeṣa sādhya dharmi dharmatāyāḥ pratipādakam iti anena eva pakṣa eka deśa asiddha bhedānām apohaḥ
translated: The statement of existence in the inferable object again is to be restricted by the exclusion of impossibility, and is the indicator of the nature of all the properties of the subject to be proved. Thus, the distinctions of being unestablished in part of the subject and so on are excluded by this alone.

analyzed: kṛtaḥ iti apārthakam yatna antaram iti yat kiñcid etat
translated: Therefore, the effort to establish it again is pointless. This is just a trifle.

analyzed: bhāvi viktaḥ api atrā eva khara rave patitaḥ
translated: Even Bhavivikta has fallen into this same pit of harsh sound.

analyzed: prakaraṇa samam anyathā samarthayati
translated: He justifies the other [type of] inconclusive [reason] as follows:

original: yasmāddhetoḥ prakaraṇacintā vipakṣasyāpi vicāraḥ paścād bhavati sa evaṃ lakṣaṇo heturnirṇayāya yopadiśyamānaḥ prakaraṇasamo bhavati /
analyzed: yasmāt hetoḥ prakaraṇa cintā vipakṣasya api vicāraḥ paścāt bhavati saḥ evam lakṣaṇaḥ hetuḥ nirṇayāya yā upadiśyamānaḥ prakaraṇasamaḥ bhavati
translated: The reason for which the consideration of the context and the examination of the counter-example occur later, that reason of such a definition, when taught for the purpose of determination, becomes inconclusive due to the context.

original: prakaraṇe sādhye samastulyaḥ sattve'sattve vā yathā satsarvajñamitaratadviparītavinirmuktatvād rūpādivaditi /
analyzed: prakaraṇe sādhye samaḥ tulyaḥ sattve sattve vā yathā sat sarvajñam itara tad viparīta vinirmukta tvāt rūpa ādi vat iti
translated: When the context is to be proved, it is equal and similar, whether it exists or does not exist, like the existence of the omniscient one, being free from the other and its opposite, like form and so on.

original: yasmādayaṃ heturubhayatra samāno yopyasatvaṃ sādhayati tasyāpi samānaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt ayam hetuḥ ubhayatra samānaḥ yaḥ upya sattvam sādhayati tasya api samānaḥ
translated: Because this reason is the same in both cases, it proves the non-existence of the omniscient one, which is also the same.

analyzed: katham asat sarvajñatvam itara tad viparīta vinirmukta tvāt khara viṣāṇa vat iti
translated: How is the non-existence of omniscience, being free from the other and its opposite, like the horn of a donkey?

analyzed: na ca ayam kila ubhaya dharma tve pi anaikāntikaḥ vipakṣa vṛttiḥ vaikalyāt
translated: And this is not inconclusive, occurring in the dissimilar class, even if it has both properties, because of the absence of that [dissimilar class].

original: tadidamācāryeṇa svayaṃ pramāṇaviniścaye pratisi /ṣiddhaṃ /🔽kampunaratra bhavān vipakṣaṃ pratyeti sādhyābhāvaṃ /
analyzed: tat idam ācāryeṇa svayam pramāṇa viniścaye pratisiṣiddham  kam punar atra bhavān vipakṣam pratyeti sādhya abhāvam
translated: This has been refuted by the master himself in the Proof of Valid Cognition.🔽And how can you here accept the dissimilar class as the absence of the probandum?

analyzed: katham idānīm hetum vipakṣa vṛttiḥ ubhaya dharmaiṇa eva ityādinā
translated: How then can you say that the reason occurs in the dissimilar class, being a property of both [similar and dissimilar classes], and so on?

analyzed: artha grahaṇa vyākhyāne ca yat uktam tat atra api vaktavyam
translated: And what was said in the explanation of the word 'object' should be said here too.

analyzed: viśeṣeṇa dūṣaṇam ca asya prapañcena uktam eva
translated: And the refutation of its distinction has been stated in detail.

analyzed: evam prakaraṇa sama atīta kālayoḥ anupapattiḥ
translated: Thus there is no possibility for the [fallacies of] inconclusive and untimely [reasons].

original: sādhyavyabhicārasya tu yujyate hetvābhāsatvaṃ na tu yathā bhavatāmabhyupagamaḥ /🔽tathā hi bhavantaḥ sandigdhavipakṣavyāvṛttikasyānaikāntikatvaṃ na pratipadyante /
analyzed: sādhya vyabhicārasya tu yujyate hetvābhāsa tvam na tu yathā bhavatām abhyupagamaḥ  tathā hi bhavantaḥ sandigdha vipakṣa vyāvṛttikasya anaikāntika tvam na pratipadyante
translated: But it is proper for the reason to be fallacious when there is deviation from the probandum, not as you accept it.🔽For you do not understand that an inconclusive [reason] is one whose exclusion from the dissimilar class is doubtful.

analyzed: adarśana mātreṇa eva vyatireka siddhi abhyupagamāt  atas eva ca bhavadbhiḥ apagata sa
translated: Because you accept that the negative concomitance is established merely by non-observation.

original: śaṅkairevaṃ prayujyate prāpyakāriṇī cakṣuḥśrotre bāhyendriyatvāt ghrāṇādivat /
analyzed: śaṅkaiḥ evam prayujyate prāpya kāriṇī cakṣuḥ śrotre bāhya indriya tvāt ghrāṇa ādi vat
translated: And for this very reason, you use it without any doubt, like this: The eye and ear function by contact, because they are external sense faculties, like the nose and so on.

original: savikalpaṃ pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇatvādanumānavadityādi /🔽na cādarśanamātreṇaiva vinā pratibandhena vyatirekesiddhiriti pratānitamanyatra /
analyzed: sa vikalpam pratyakṣam pramāṇa tvāt anumāna vat ityādi  na ca adarśana mātreṇa eva vinā pratibandhena vyatireke siddhiḥ iti pratānitam anyatra
translated: Perception with conceptual construction is a means of valid knowledge, because it is perception, like inference, etc.🔽And mere non-apprehension cannot establish the vyatireka without a relation, as has been explained elsewhere.

analyzed: ātma mṛd cetanā ādīnām yaḥ bhāvasya a prasādhakaḥ
translated: The non-apprehension of soul, intellect, sentience, etc. is not a proof of the non-existence of an entity.

original: sa evānupalambhaḥ kiṃ hetvabhāvasya sādhaka ityādinā /
analyzed: saḥ eva anupalambhaḥ kim hetu abhāvasya sādhakaḥ ityādinā
translated: How can it be a proof of the absence of a reason? etc.

original: tathā sapakṣavipakṣayoḥ sandigdhaḥ sadasatvasyāpi samyagjñānahetutvameva yuṣmābhiriṣyate nānaikāntikatvaṃ yathā sātmakaṃ jīvaccharīramprāṇādimattvāditi
analyzed: tathā sapakṣa vipakṣayoḥ sandigdhaḥ sat asatvasya api samyak jñāna hetu tvam eva yuṣmābhiḥ iṣyate na anaikāntika tvam yathā sātmakam jīvat śarīram prāṇa ādimat tvāt iti
translated: Similarly, the existence or non-existence of a reason in similar and dissimilar instances is accepted by you as the cause of true knowledge, not as inconclusive, just as the living body is endowed with soul because it is endowed with life, etc.

original: asya ca tadbhāvaḥ pratipāditaḥ pramāṇaviniścayā dau viruddhaprabhedastu bhāradvājavihitaḥ pratijñāvirodhaprastāva ieva nirākṛtaḥ /🔽sādhyasamepi yoyamanyathāsiddho varṇyate yathā'nityāḥ paramāṇavaḥ kriyāvatvād ghaṭadivaditi ayamapi kila sādhyasamo yasmāt mūrtikriyārūpādimatvādaṇūnāṃ
analyzed: asya ca tad bhāvaḥ pratipāditaḥ pramāṇa viniścayāḥ viruddha prabhedaḥ tu bhāradvāja vihitaḥ pratijñā virodha prastāvaḥ nirākṛtaḥ  sādhyasame api yaḥ yam anyathā asiddhaḥ varṇyate yathā anityāḥ paramāṇavaḥ kriyāvat tvāt ghaṭa di vat iti ayam api kila sādhyasamaḥ yasmāt mūrti kriyā rūpa ādima tvāt aṇūnām
translated: And this has been shown to be the same. The distinction of contradictory [reasons] has been refuted by Bharadvaja in the context of the contradiction of the proposition itself.🔽Even the one described as being otherwise established, like atoms are impermanent because they are endowed with action, like a pot, etc., is also said to be the same as the probandum, because the atoms' endowment with action is not due to impermanence,

analyzed: kriyāvat tvam na anitya tvāt iti
translated: but due to having form, action, color, etc.

analyzed: sa na upapadyate
translated: That is not correct.

original: dharmiṇi siddhatvānnahi dharmiṇi vidyamāna evāsiddho heturyujyate /
analyzed: dharmiṇi siddha tvāt na hi dharmiṇi vidyamānaḥ eva asiddhaḥ hetuḥ yujyate
translated: Because the subject is established. Indeed, it is not proper for an unestablished reason to exist in the subject.

analyzed: sarve hetūnām asiddha tā prasaṅgāt  na etat evat nahi prakṣā īsti iti etāvatā pakṣa dharma tvam
translated: Because it would follow that all reasons are unestablished.🔽This is not so, because mere non-existence of the reason is not the property of the subject.

analyzed: sādhya vaśena hi dharmiṇaḥ pakṣa dharma tvam iṣyate
translated: For the property of the subject is accepted to be the property of the subject by virtue of the probandum.

original: kevalasya sādhyatvāt /🔽na ca sādhyo dharmo yadi dharmiṇi tena sādhanena vinā na sambhavati tasya ca sādhanasya sādhyadharmābhāve dharmiṇā sambhavastato hetoḥ pakṣadharmatvaṃ
analyzed: kevalasya sādhya tvāt  na ca sādhyaḥ dharmaḥ yadi dharmiṇi tena sādhanena vinā na sambhavati tasya ca sādhanasya sādhya dharma abhāve dharmiṇā sambhavaḥ tatas hetoḥ pakṣa dharma tvam
translated: Because it is only the probandum.🔽And if the probandum is not possible in the subject without that probans, and that probans is possible in the subject even in the absence of the probandum, then the reason has the property of the subject.

original: yadā punaranyathāpi sādhanāyopātte dharmiṇi dharma upapadyate tadā hetuttvamevañca viśiṣṭameva satvaṃ pakṣadharmatvena vivakṣitaṃ /
analyzed: yadā punar anyathā api sādhanāya upātte dharmiṇi dharmaḥ upapadyate tadā viśiṣṭam eva satvam pakṣa dharma tvena vivakṣitam
translated: But when the property is possible in the subject even when the probans is adduced in another way, then it is a reason. Thus, mere existence qualified in this way is intended to be the property of the subject.

analyzed: anyathā asiddha tvam yuktam eva sādhyasamam
translated: Otherwise, it is proper to say that it is not established in another way, which is the same as the probandum.

original: tadidamatra pratividhānaṃ yadi khalu sādhyadharmābhāve dharmiṇi asambhavo hetorevaṃ vidhameva satvaṃ pakṣadharmatvena vivakṣitaṃ na tu bhāvamātraṃ
analyzed: tat idam atra pratividhānam yadi khalu sādhya dharma abhāve dharmiṇi asambhavaḥ hetoḥ evaṃvidham eva satvam pakṣa dharma tvena vivakṣitam na tu bhāva mātram
translated: This is the answer to the above: If the impossibility of the reason in the subject when the property to be established is absent is meant to be the nature of the reason as the property of the subject, and not mere existence,

original: tadā kintaditthaṃbhūtaṃ pakṣadharmatvamavijñātamevānumeyaprakāśakamāhosvit pariniścitameveti prakāradvaye yadyavijñātaṃ prakāśakaṃ tadājñāpakahetunyāyamativarttate
analyzed: tadā kin tat itthaṃbhūtam pakṣa dharma tvam avijñātam eva anumeya prakāśakam āhosvit pariniścitam eva iti prakāra dvaye yadi avijñātam prakāśakam tadā ājñāpaka hetu nyāyam ativarttate
translated: then is that nature of the reason as the property of the subject to be known or not known when it is made manifest by the inference? In the two alternatives, if it is not known, then it goes beyond the principle of the probans.

original: jñāpako hi hetuḥ svātmani jñānāpekṣo jñāpyamarthaṃ prakāśayati /
analyzed: jñāpakaḥ hi hetuḥ sva ātmani jñāna apekṣaḥ jñāpyam artham prakāśayati
translated: For the probans illuminates the object to be known by its own nature, depending on knowledge.

original: sattā mātreṇa ca hetavo vipratipattinirākāraṇapaṭavaḥ santīti prativādināṃ parasparaparāhataṃ pravacananānātvaṃ na bhavet /
analyzed: sattā mātreṇa ca hetavaḥ vipratipatti nirākāraṇa paṭavaḥ santi iti prativādinām paraspara parāhatam pravacana nānātvam na bhavet
translated: And the probans are capable of removing the disagreement by mere existence, so the various teachings of the disputants would not be mutually contradictory.

original: vijñātasyāpi gamakatve pramāṇādvā tasya pariniścayaḥ pramāṇādvā /
analyzed: vijñātasya api gamaka tve pramāṇāt vā tasya pariniścayaḥ pramāṇāt vā
translated: If the known is also the probans, then its ascertainment is either by a means of valid knowledge or by another means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: na tāvat apramāṇasya bhūta artha niścaya hetu tva abhāvāt apramāṇāt gatiḥ anyathā prāmāṇyam evā avahīyate
translated: Not by a means of valid knowledge, because it is not the cause of the ascertainment of the real object. The known is not the means of knowledge, otherwise it would lose its validity.

analyzed: yasmāt idam eva pramāṇasya pramāṇa tvam yat yathā avasthita vastu prakāśaka tvam
translated: Because this alone is the validity of a means of valid knowledge, that it illuminates an object as it exists.

original: taccedamapramāṇasyāpyasti tadā kathaṃ tada pramāṇātsādhye dharmiṇi vinā sādhyadharmeṇāsadbhūṣṇorhetoḥ sattvampakṣadharmatvenādhigamyate tadāpi
analyzed: tat ca idam apramāṇasya api asti tadā katham pramāṇāt sādhye dharmiṇi vinā sādhya dharmeṇa asat bhūṣṇoḥ hetoḥ sattvam pakṣa dharma tvena adhigamyate tadā api
translated: And if this exists even for a non-means of valid knowledge, then how is the existence of the reason, which is non-existent in the probandum property in the probandum property-possessor which is to be established by that means of valid knowledge, understood as the property of the subject? Even then,

original: yata eva pramāṇāddhetoḥ siddhistata eva sādhyadharmasyāpītaṃ jāyata iti kimarthamayamakiñcitkaro heturūpādīyate /
analyzed: yatas eva pramāṇāt hetoḥ siddhiḥ tatas eva sādhya dharmasya apītam jāyate iti kimartham ayam akiñcitkaraḥ hetuḥ ūpādīyate
translated: from that very means of valid knowledge by which the reason is established, the probandum property also arises. So for what purpose is this useless reason stated?

original: na ca hetoreva kevalasya tataḥ siddhiḥ sādhyadharmasya tu neti yuktamvaktuṃ hetorapi tato'siddhiprasaṅgāt tathā hyevamayaṃ htuḥ tatra dharmiṇi
analyzed: na ca hetoḥ eva kevalasya tatas siddhiḥ sādhya dharmasya tu nā iti yuktam vaktum hetoḥ api tatas siddhi prasaṅgāt tathā hi evam ayam htuḥ tatra dharmiṇi
translated: And it is not proper to say that only the reason is established by that, but not the probandum property, because then the reason also would not be established by that. For thus this reason is established in that property-possessor

original: sidhyati yadyanena sādhyadharmeṇa vineha nopapadyate sahaiva tūpapadyata iti sidhyet /
analyzed: sidhyati yadi anena sādhya dharmeṇa vinā iha na upapadyate saha eva tu upapadyate iti sidhyet
translated: if it is not possible without that probandum property, but is possible only together with it.

original: tathā ca kathantata eva pramāṇātsādhyadharmasyāpi na siddhiḥ sañjāteti cintanīyametat /
analyzed: tathā ca katham tatas eva pramāṇāt sādhya dharmasya api na siddhiḥ sañjātā iti cintanīyam etat
translated: And if so, then how is it that the probandum property is not also established from that same means of valid knowledge? This should be considered.🔽And in this way, this probandum property of it,

analyzed: evam ca tena eva pramāṇena saha asya sādhya dharmasya
translated: together with that same means of valid knowledge,

analyzed: gamya gamaka bhāvaḥ na tu anena hetunā iti mahat aniṣṭam āpadyate
translated: And it is not the relation of probans and probandum that is established by this reason. Thus a great evil is incurred.

original: evamvidhapakṣadharmatvasamāśrayaṇe ca yāvat sādhyasyāsiddhistāvaddhetorapi yāvacca hetorasiddhistāvatsādhyasyāpīti parasparāśrayaprasaṅgaḥ
analyzed: evamvidha pakṣa dharma tva samāśrayaṇe ca yāvat sādhyasya asiddhiḥ tāvat hetoḥ api yāvat ca hetoḥ asiddhiḥ tāvat sādhyasya api iti paraspara āśraya prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And when such a property of the subject is relied upon, as long as the probandum is not established, so long the reason also is not established, and as long as the reason is not established, so long the probandum also is not established. Thus there is the contingence of mutual dependence.

original: pakṣadharmatvaniścayavelāyāñca sādhyadharmasiddhiḥ sampadyata iti vyarthamuttaraliṅgarūpānusaraṇamitthañca na dvilakṣaṇaścaturlakṣaṇaḥ pañcalakṣaṇaśca
